August 24th,
1929.

The Secretary,
The Department of Indian Affairs,
Ottawa, Ont.

Dear Sir:

The communication of Mr. Russell T. Ferrier, Superintendent of Indian Education, dated August 15th, addressed to Rev. Robt. B. Cochrane, D.D., is to hand, referring to the White Cap Sioux Indian Day School, which was taught by Mrs. A. L. Fakeley, and to the fact that the school was open only twelve days during the quarter ended June 30th last.

The Department is asking for the advice of this office in regard to a suitable payment under the circumstances that the short period for which the school was taught was due, first, to the illness of the teacher, and then to the close of the school owing to an outbreak of whooping cough.

We find it difficult to advise the Department in regard to this matter, but would state that Mrs. Fakeley's salary has been paid in full by this office, and we are quite willing to leave the matter entirely to the judgment of the Department to send us whatever they think is just and fair.

Yours most faithfully,

[Signature]

CANADA
Ottawa, July 5th, 1929.

Sir,

I have to inform you that the authorities of the United Church of Canada have nominated the services of Miss H. J. Hare as teacher of the Moose Woods (Whitecap Sioux) Indian Day School for the next school year. The Department is approving of her appointment, with salary at the rate of $90 per teaching month. I have to request that you will give Miss Hare every assistance you can upon her taking up duties at this school.

Your obedient servant,

A. F. MacKenzie,
Acting Asst. Deputy & Secretary.

C. P. Schmidt, Esq.,
Indian Agent,
Duck Lake, Sask.

CANADA
Ottawa, June 20, 1935.

Sir:

I have to inform you that the authorities of the United Church of Canada, under whose auspices the Whitecap (Moose Woods) Indian Day School is conducted, have nominated the services of Mrs. Ellen C. Carlin, to succeed Miss Helen J. Hare, as from September third, next, the date the school re-opens after the summer holidays. The Department is approving of her appointment, with salary at the rate of $90 per teaching month.

I have to request that you will give Mrs. Carlin every assistance you can in her work at this school.

Mr. Inspector Murison is being informed of the approval granted for this appointment.

Your obedient servant,

A. F. MacKenzie,
Secretary.

C. P. Schmidt, Esq.,
Indian Agent,
Duck Lake, Sask.

APPROVED BY MINISTER:-
see memo. dated June 14th,
returned & rec'd. June 19th

Ottawa, July 12, 1946.

Memorandum:

REPRESENTATIVE OF THE TREASURY

Re: Whitecap Sioux Indian Day School No. 625.

The Department has received and accepted the resignation of the teacher, Mrs. E. C. Carlin, effective July 1, 1946, and no further payment of salary should be made to her after that date.

For Deputy Minister.
Duck Lake, Sask.,
November 14, 1946.

Dept. of Mines & Resources,
Indian Affairs Branch,
Ottawa, Ontario.

With reference to Departmental letter No. 80-109 (FA 1)
dated November 9th, I beg to advise that up to the present time
we have not been able to obtain a teacher for the Moose Woods
Sioux Indian Day School.

Mrs. Carlin the former teacher resigned her position
last June, which fact was submitted to the Department by letter
No. 312-15-94 dated July 3rd from this office.

Repeated calls have been made on the United Church
Mission, 201 C.P.R. Building, Saskatoon, with a view to having
them obtain a man teacher for this Reserve but without success
as at this date.

Every effort is being made to get a teacher for this
reserve but due to a shortage of teachers and with the much brighter
future for teachers in the outside schools, it is getting more
difficult all the time to get teachers for our Indian Day Schools.

Immediately a teacher is located for this school and
classes are again being taught, reports as requested in your
letter will be forwarded.

N. J. McLEOD

Indian Agent

WM GRAHAM
OTTAWA, July 12th, 1922.

Sir:

Replying to your telegram of the 8th instant, regarding tenders for a combined day school and teacher's residence for the White Car Sioux Reserve, I beg to say that the need for this building was brought to the attention of the Department by the Methodist Church authorities on several occasions during the past two years. They stated that it was absolutely impossible to station a teacher there, as there was no building in which he could live. The Department also understands that the school building is most unsuitable. The Church authorities urged that provision be made in our estimates for the current fiscal year for the erection of a combined school and teacher's residence.

A communication from the Superintendent of Indian Education forwarded from Regina during his recent visit states as follows:

"The Rev. Ferrier of Brandon, Commissioner Graham of Regina, and myself have discussed this matter and we are of the opinion that not more than $4000 should be spent building the necessary equipment. We have agreed that it is unnecessary to build, but a small school with seating accommodation for twenty-five and residential facilities for a man and his wife and perhaps a child is quite sufficient. Nothing expensive or elaborate should be in the specifications."

In view of this, the Department immediately undertook the preparation of the plans for a combined school and teacher's residence, copies of which were sent you on the 27th ultimo.

Until your telegram was received, we were not aware that the Indians were putting up a school building. However, if this building is satisfactory, we will be prepared to supply any furnishings or any material required to complete the building. The question of erecting a residence can be considered separately from the school building, provided you are satisfied that the building which is nearly completed by the Indians would be satisfactory for school purposes. We have the money provided in this year's estimates, and I shall be pleased to hear from you as to whether any material or equipment is required to complete the building now in course of erection, and also whether the building of a teacher's residence should be proceeded with this year.

W. M. Graham, Esq.,
Indian Commissioner,
Regina, Sask.

Further to our conversation on the telephone Saturday morning last, when I acknowledged receipt of your No.306-14A, dated the 6th inst., enclosing copy of letter addressed to the Postmasters at Saskatoon and Durndurn re tenders for the erection of a combined Day school and Teachers house on the Whitecap Sioux reserve, near Duck Lake.

I beg to say that I have just returned from this reserve and found, as stated over the Phone, that the Band under the supervision of Mr. Chas. Miner of Miner & Ball Ltd., Building Contractors of Saskatoon, had started work on the erection of a school house on the reserve, the cost of which the band is to pay by subscriptions taken among themselves.

The building they are erecting is of the following dimensions and materials, viz:

Outside measurement, 18 x 28 feet.
Ceiling, 9 feet clear from finish floor.
Foundation, Concrete, 8 x 8 inches.
Outside walls, ship lap, sheeting, two (2) ply paper cedar bevel siding with base board drip cap, etc.
Roofing, ship lap and No.1 cedar shingles.
Studding, 2x4, 16 inch centers.
Ceiling Joists, 2x6, 16 inch centers.
Gutters, 2x4, two (2) foot centers, crown foot on plates 10 inch rise to 12 inch run.
Floor Joists, 2x6x18, two (2) feet centers, 6 to 8 inches from ground, beam filling.
Flooding, rough floor ship lap, finish floor edge grain fir.
Inside Walls & Ceiling, lath & plaster with base board.
Lighting, "even windows, 24x24, two (2) lights, 5 of these are on left "North" wall and two on front, "West" wall, one on each side of door "entrance".
Chimney, Brick in North West corner of building, with soot pan and stove pipe hole.

The following work has already been done, viz:
Hauling of material purchased from Miner, Ball & Nelson Co., Ltd., as per list attached, the foundation, rough walls "sheeting", roof boards, rough floor, & placing of windows & door frames.

I have had the work stopped until further instructions.

Mr. Miner who started and supervised the work so far is not to do so any longer, when the band placed with his Firm the order for the material.
he promised them one days work free of charge, he stayed with them a second day, as he wanted to see the work properly started.

The Indians cannot continue the work without an experienced man supervising same, because if left to themselves to complete the building they will spoil same.

I now ask that the Department take over the building as it stands, also the account for the material supplied as per list attached, and complete same, also build a teachers residence adjoining, annexed to the school room, as was their intention when calling for tenders for a combined Day-school and Teachers residence.

I would suggest that two hot air pipes, leading from the furnace in the teachers house, be placed in the school.

That wainscoting be put all around the class room.

That proper black boards be installed along the right "South", and last walls, with proper chalk trough or moulding at the bottom.

The Teachers house should have a kitchen, living and dining room and three bedrooms upstairs, a basement with furnace, soft water cistern tank, a vegetable room partitioned off, and space for at least one cord of wood.

The teachers house should face south.

The soil is very, very light, "sand".

The band asks that the building be painted white with dark green trimmings & light green paint on the roof, these colors I recommend.

I did not measure the height from the top of the foundation to the peak of the roof, but I think that if the Teachers house is built with gable ends facing North and South, that the top of the plate on 16 foot studdings will come about level with the peak of the school roof.

While the Indians did, on several occasions, tell me of their intention of building a new school themselves, they did not inform me of their intention of building so soon, and made their arrangement for the purchase of the material without my knowledge, which they now very much regret.

I note that the Notice calling for tenders reads (On the Whitecap Sioux reserve------near Duck Lake). Should this not read on the Moose Woods Sioux Reserve near Dundurn Sask., Dundurn is 13 miles & Saskatoon 20 to 22 miles from the reserve.

Yours truly,

Indian Agent.

W.M. Graham, Esq.
Indian Commissioner,
Regina, Sask.

Dear Mr. Scott:

On the 3rd of July I received your letter dated the 27th of June informing me that plans and specifications had been prepared for a combined day school and teacher's residence for White Cap Sioux Reserve, and asking me to obtain and submit to the Department, tenders for this building.

In accordance with your request I prepared notices and had them posted in Saskatoon, Regina and Dundurn. After these notices were posted I received a long distance phone from Agent Schmidt of Duck Lake, informing me that the Indians of the Reserve had undertaken to build a school on their own account and had the building nearly completed. In view of the fact that the tenders were already posted, I communicated with you by wire on the 8th instant, asking you what you wished me to do in the matter. Today is the 15th and I have had no instructions.

I received this morning, the attached letter from Mr. Agent Schmidt in which he makes a request that the Department take over the school that has been nearly completed by the Indians. I question very much whether it would be a good plan to do this. I cannot act on anything that Agent Schmidt suggests until I know what the Department's attitude in the matter will be. He had no authority from me to have the building stopped, he took this upon himself.

Duncan C. Scott, Esq.,
Deputy Superintendent General,
Dept. of Indian Affairs,
Ottawa, Ont.
As no request was made by me for a school at the Moose Woods Sioux Reserve, it has just occurred to me that probably it was not intended that a school should be built there, as you refer to the White Cap Sioux near Dundurn. Is it possible that a mistake was made in Ottawa and that this school should be for the White Cap Sioux Reserve near Prince Albert, as it is near that point where I understand, a school is needed.

I will be glad to have your instructions in this matter.

Yours very truly,

Sir:

I have to acknowledge the receipt of your letter of the 17th instant, giving a list of the supplies that will be required each month in the providing of a midday meal to the children of the Whitecap Sioux Indian Day School.

In reply I beg to say that you may arrange for the purchase and delivery each month of the following supplies:

- Beef - 20 Lbs.
- Oatmeal - 10 Lbs.
- Lard - 5 #
- Sugar - 10 #
- Tea - 2 #
- Soap - 5 #
- Rice - 2 #
- Potatoes - 1 Bu.
- Beans - 6 #
- Baking Powder - 1 Lb.

The quantities mentioned above should not be exceeded.

We are not prepared to furnish cocoa, corn starch, tapioca, evaporated apples or prunes.

If possible competitive prices should be obtained for the furnishing of the above supplies each month.

You may purchase a flour bin, and the cost should not exceed your estimate of approximately $4.

Regarding fuel for the teacher's residence, I beg to say that the Department will pay for the fuel required for the residence and for the preparation of the children's meals. You may, therefore, arrange from time to time for the purchase of the fuel required - wood or coal. Only the quantity of fuel absolutely necessary for the above purpose should be supplied. Competitive prices should be obtained, if possible, and the fuel purchased from the person quoting the lowest price.

Regarding the wood for the school, it is considered that the Indians, as in the past, should continue to supply the quantity required for the school room, free of charge.

Regarding the providing of more accommodation in connection with the teacher's residence, I beg to say that you should state the cost of the material in erecting an addition of, say, 12' at the back of the present teacher's residence. You should also ascertain whether the teacher will, with the help of Indian labour, undertake the erection

MEMO. FOR FILE:

Public School Inspector Anderson reports that at the time of his visit to the White Cap Sioux Indian Day School (June 12) he found

1. no screen doors,
2. no blinds,
3. no towels or mirror,
4. unsatisfactory condition of the outdoor lavatories.

The Inspector reports that the stove is too small for winter purposes, and recommends a larger one with jacket. He also recommends that a kitchen be built at the back of the teacher's residence. The fencing has not been used as it is lying on the ground, and the well is only partly dug.

The Inspector expresses the opinion that the Indian agent, who lives at some distance, is not seriously concerned with improvement at this school.
Ottawa, June 28, 1923.

Sir:

I have to inform you that the Department is in receipt of Public school Inspector Anderson's report on the White Cap Sioux Indian Day School. The Inspector reports that some of the work we have authorized has not been completed. On the day of his visit (June 12) there were no screen doors and the fence was not up. Further, the well was only partly dug. In the light of your No. 7047-115-94 of the 2nd instant, enclosing voucher No. 646, the Department is of the opinion that this work should have been completed. I shall be pleased to have a report from you in this connection.

The Inspector recommends that the windows be equipped with blinds and that a mirror be supplied, also some towels. I should be pleased if you would make arrangements for the purchase and delivery of this equipment, in time for the re-opening of the school on September first.

It is reported, also, that the outdoor closets are under one roof, with but a thin partition and with seats that are altogether too high. The Inspector recommends a second closet to be built and the present one remodelled. I shall be pleased to have your recommendation in this connection.

I wish to draw your attention to the last paragraph of official communication of the 24th of April, last, (File No. 109-11-1). You were asked to estimate the cost of erecting a 12 ft. addition at the back of the present teacher's residence. June 6th, 1923.

C.P. Schmidt, Esq.,
Duck Lake, Sask.

Dear sir,

In regard to the construction of an addition to the residence here, permit me to state that I do not think that the suggestion of the Department, that the work should be done by the Indians, is feasible for several reasons.

For one thing it is doubtful if the Indians can be relied upon to give sufficient attention to the work. They are kept quite busy at their own tasks and in all probability would find but little time to devote to building. In order to avoid loss of time, errors in construction, and waste of material, as well as to insure complete and permanent satisfaction, I believe that the construction should be undertaken by experienced workmen.

I remain,

Yours truly,

Sgd. G.M. Churchill.
Reference the last paragraph of your letter No. 109-11-1, dated April 24th, 1923, regarding the providing of more accommodation in connection with the teacher's residence on Moose Woods reserve.

I have the honour to inform you that I have made known to Mr. Churchill, the teacher on the reserve, the department's view in the matter, and am attaching hereto a copy of his reply.

I do not approve of having this work done by the Indians, none of whom are handy with tools, and defective work on the addition would spoil the looks of the building and probably require repairs to same, or patching, in a short time.

I recommend that the addition be built by experienced workmen and that a thorough job be done, and would recommend that Miners & Hall Limited, who erected the cottage, be given the work as they will know without going out to see the building exactly what is to be done in order to join both buildings under one roof, and would know what to start at when they arrived at the place.

The approximate cost of the material will be $295.00, plus freighting of material to the reserve, and board of men while working.

I recommend that the work be done as soon as possible and during the holidays.

I have the honour to be

Sir,

Sir,

I have the honour to report that I am in receipt of a communication from Mr. G.M. Churchill, Teacher of the Moose Woods Reserve Day School, which reads:

"Dear Sir,- I would like to know if it would be possible to have the present school stove replaced by one of a different type, preferably a sheet steel heater, unless a regular Waterbury Heater could be installed.

The present stove is unsatisfactory with the type of wood available, is slow to heat up and radiates no heat low down where it is most needed. A sheet steel heater would quickly heat the building, would make a more economical use of the fuel and would maintain the warmth of the room on a very cold day, when the present stove is almost useless.

For the comfort of the children and to promote the efficiency of the school work a change in the heating plant is necessary."

The stove now in use is an ordinary cast iron box stove. The fuel, wood, supplied the school by the Indians is very small, burns quickly, and does not hold a fire in the stove any length of time.

I recommend that I be authorized to purchase a sheet steel heater and have same installed in the school room in lieu of the box stove now used. The cost of a sheet iron heater will be about $20.00. If possible I will try to trade in the box stove for a heater.

I have the honour to be

Sir,

Your obedient servant,

C.P. Schmidt,
Indian Agent.

MOOSE WOODS DAY SCHOOL

This school is taught by Mrs. Fakeley, who is appointed by the United Church.

There are 12 on the roll,- 8 girls and 4 boys. Seven were present on the day of inspection. However, they were all in junior grades, in fact, very few could speak English. These children appear very shy and timid and when a stranger is present, they are much worse. I believe Mrs. Fakeley is winning their confidence and in time should accomplish good work.

The children were clean and tidy, and the classroom was in splendid condition. It was re-decorated this year and is very bright and cheerful.

The heater used is absolutely worn out and is not safe. This is a practically new school and it is a pity to take such chances with an old stove.

The teacher's residence is in good repair and, I believe, quite comfortable. Here, again, a new heater is badly needed. Mrs. Fakeley requested that a coal heater be purchased, as wood is not procurable on the reserve, and that furnished is a poor grade of balm which will not hold fire. She is obliged to get up two and three times each night to re-fill the stove in order to keep the house warm. The stove is only a cheap tin stove and it is not safe to go away and leave on a fire. A stove certainly should be...
MOOSE WOODS DAY SCHOOL (Cont'd.)

should be provided and I believe a coal burner would be best.

Signed R.G. Hamilton

Dear Mr. Scott:

Miss H. J. Hare is in charge at this school, and I was pleased to note that progress is being made under her direction. These children have always been very backward, and this is the first occasion I have been able to hear them read or answer questions.

The roll calls for 12, and all were present. The girls number 7, and boys 5. There are 8 children in Grade I, and 4 in Grade II. However, as stated above, there is marked progress, and if Miss Hare remains, I have no doubt advancement will be made. The average attendance is 10, which is very gratifying.

The school was clean and well aired, and the children were well clothed and tidy.

The school building needs exterior painting, and the teacher's residence is in need of both interior and exterior decoration. A fence about these buildings would improve the surroundings.

February 23rd, 1931.

Inspector Hamilton's Report on the schools in the
Duck Lake Agency.

Dear Mr. Graham:

I have the honour to submit the following report on the schools of the Duck Lake Agency, inspected during my stay there between January 27th and February 14th, 1931.

MOOSE WOODS INDIAN DAY SCHOOL

The roll calls for 13 pupils, and I found 12 present, 7 girls and 5 boys. The grades are arranged as follows:

Grade I - 2
II - 7
III - 3
IV - 1

The attendance has been good, and for the month of January the average was 12.15.

The children were neatly dressed, and were clean in appearance. Their books are all neatly kept, and the work nicely set down. They speak out much better than on other occasions, and appear to take an interest in their school.

Miss H. J. Hare is a capable teacher, and already these children have showed marked improvement in their manners, as well as in their school work.

The school and residence are in good repair, but both buildings are badly in need of painting. A fence would also improve the surroundings and be a protection to the buildings.

W. M. Graham, Esq.,
Indian Commissioner,
Regina, Sask.

Dear Mr. Scott:

I beg to forward herewith a very satisfactory report on the schools in the Duck Lake Agency, comprising three day schools and one Residential school.

You will note that at the Moose Woods Day School there is an enrolment of 13 pupils, with an average attendance of 12.15 and that the children are neatly dressed and clean in appearance. This speaks very well for the parents on this reserve, who are not under the guidance of a White Instructor, but merely under the influence of the teacher, Miss Hare, who is quite capable. The Inspector points out that the school and residence are in good repair, but that both buildings are badly in need of painting, and that a fence is also required. I would point out that $150.00 was placed in the Estimates for painting and $85.00 for a fence. I should be glad to see these items approved.

Sir-

Reference Departmental letter #109-II-5 dated November 19th last re a coal stove heater for the Moose Woods Sioux Reserve Day School and asking me to inform the Department of the difference in cost as between wood and coal. I have the honour to state that in the past the fuel (wood) for this class-room has been supplied by the Indians gratis.

The wood used by the Indians of this reserve for heating their homes is mostly large Willow brush, which they gather around the sloughs and low lands, this they burn in Air Tight Heaters as the billet is too small to burn in an ordinary cast iron box stove.

The supply of this wood is not plentiful on the reserve, and the Indians pick the best pieces for their homes and bring the poorer pieces to the school. Those who have no children attending school are very lax about bringing their share. All seem to think they should be paid for the wood supplied.

Miss H.J. Hare the present Teacher who took charge of the school in September 1930, has complained every winter about the quality and sometimes the quantity of wood supplied. I have taken this matter up with the Indians, and several times with the Overseer Chas. R. Eagle, but their promises that a good supply will be prepared at once seem to be forgotten after I leave the reserve.

There seems to be a (chilled) feeling towards the Teacher on the part of some of the Indians, the Overseer is one of them. I tried to get to the source of the trouble but found it touched, as I thought, on Missionary (Church) matters, I would not discuss it.

The cost of burning coal and wood in the class-room would be approximately:

Wood. 20 Cords @ $7.00 delivered in stove lengths $140.00
Coal. 10 Tons @ $12.00 " $120.00

If coal is used it will be necessary to erect a coal shed near the school at a cost of approximately $50.00. A suitable coal stove will cost approximately $20.00, if we continue to use wood a shed is not required.

A large size Air Tight Heater suitable for the building will cost approximately $18.00. The ordinary cheap tin heater now in use is badly burnt and will not be fit for use another season.

I recommend burning wood as in the past and purchasing same from the Indians. I talked the matter over with Miss Hare the Teacher when on the reserve last week, who said she would be quite satisfied providing a good supply was on hand all the time, then she would not have to send notes to the Overseer to tell him the supply was getting low.

I have the honour to be
Sir
Your obedient servant,
C.P. Schmidt Indian Agent.

Sir:

I have your letter of the first instant, regarding the change in the fuel used in the heating of the Moose Woods (Sioux Reserve) Indian Day School. In this connection it is noted you recommend that the burning of wood, as in the past, be continued and that it be purchased from the Indians, rather than the use of coal and the supplying of a stove and a coal shed.

The Department considers that it would be satisfactory, for the present at least, to continue the use of wood as fuel and will approve of paying the Indians for delivering the quantity of a good grade of wood required. Therefore, you may arrange with the Indians to deliver, cut into proper stove lengths, the quantity of wood required for the present winter's use. It is noted that the cost will be $7.00 per cord. You should arrange to have them deliver the quantity required at an early date, and, when the wood has been supplied to your satisfaction, please forward certified accounts, in duplicate, in favour of the Indians who deliver it, for the amount due them. The wood should be properly piled or stored at the school.

When it is necessary to obtain the supply for use in the winter of 1932-33, you should make application to the Department for authority to incur the expenditure required in supplying the wood.

Sir:

I beg to forward herewith Provincial School Inspector H.A. Evans' report on the Moose Woods Indian Day School.

I may point out that the buildings are very badly in need of paint, as a matter of fact the paint has practically disappeared from the walls of the buildings. The interiors of both the school room and the teacher's residence are badly in need of redecorating and repairs. The buildings are located on a sand bank and it is a difficult matter to have a garden; although I feel sure that if the teacher had sufficient interest a plot of ground could be found. There is a considerable quantity of woven wire on hand which has been rolled up to provide a fence for a garden. I noted that the children were provided with a ball and a bat, but no other facilities for recreation are provided. These things can be corrected when the services of a teacher who will take an active interest in the welfare of the pupils is appointed.

Your obedient servant,

W. Murison.

Inspector of Indian Agencies.
Saskatchewan.
Ottawa, July 13, 1935.

Sir:

Mr. Inspector Murison has forwarded the report of the Provincial School Inspector on the Moose Woods Indian Day School. Mr. Murison states he was present at the time of the inspection.

As you have already been informed, a change in teacher is being made at this school for the coming academic year.

Mr. Murison points out that the buildings are very badly in need of paint. He states the interiors of both the classroom and the teacher's residence require redecorating and repairs. I would request that you examine this building and inform the Department what painting, renovations and repairs you would recommend be carried out, giving an estimate of the cost. Please report, also, regarding the labour. Could the work be performed satisfactorily by Indian labour, or would it be necessary to have outside help? When submitting your estimate, I shall be pleased if you will report on the cost of renovating the interior of the school and teacher's residence separately from the cost of the outside painting of the buildings. As our funds are extremely limited it may only be possible to fix up the interior. However, when your estimate is received, consideration will be given as to what work can be authorized.

Mr. Murison states, further, that as the buildings are located on a sand bank, it is a difficult matter to have a garden, although, if the teacher had sufficient interest, a plot of ground could be found. He states there is a considerable quantity of woven wire on hand, rolled up which would provide a fence for the garden. You should state if you would recommend that provision be made for a garden at this school. If so, the cost of any extra wire, posts, etc., and the labour in erecting same should be stated.

Your obedient servant,

A. F. MacKenzie,
Secretary.

Dear Sir:

Re. MOOSE WOODS SIOUX INDIAN RESERVE  
School Buildings.

We beg to quote as follows for Painting the Interior and Exterior of the School and Teacherage.

1. **Interior of School.** Repair plaster and apply two coats kalsomine to walls and ceilings. Properly prepare, and apply two coats of paint to all the woodwork including wainscoting and V-joint finish of the entrance vestibule. Paint the whole floor two coats.

2. **Exterior of School.** Supply and set in place approximately 50 lin ft of 1" x 10" sill board (rotted beyond painting). Scrape and wire brush all exterior wood trim and siding. Putty all windows, apply three coats pure lead paint to all woodwork. Apply two coats pure linseed oil stain to the roof shingles. This to include the two outhouses which will be painted the same as the School.

3. **Interior of Teacherage.** Prepare, and apply two coats oil paint to all the V-joint walls and ceiling of all rooms throughout including wood trim. Paint the floors two coats.

4. **Exterior of Teacherage.** Scrape and wire brush all exterior wood trim and siding including porch floor, apply to all three coats pure lead paint after puttying up. Apply two coats pure linseed oil stain to all the roof shingles. This to include the Teacherage outhouse.

All labour, materials, transportation, etc., required to properly carry out the work, general labour conditions of Dominion Department of Public Works contracts to govern.

Sir:

Reference Departmental letter #109-11-5 dated the 13th ultimo re painting and decorating interior of classroom and teachers residence at the Moose Woods Sioux Reserve Day School, I have the honour to enclose herewith quotation received from P.J. Philpott and Company of Saskatoon who sent one of their representatives to the reserve to look over the buildings and carefully check the work to be done.

Sir;-

I beg to advise that Mrs H.C. Carlin, Teacher of the Whitecap Indian Day School wrote on January the 26th., asking for a further supply of Drimilk. On the 17th., instance I wrote her requesting an explanation as to why more was needed, and this day received a letter from her which reads as follows:-

"I hereby make application for an order of Drimilk to carry on the school lunches to the close of the period, namely, March 24th. This need for extra supply of milk arises in the fact of an increase enrollment of pupils for this term and also in that the pupils through the severity of weather have been bringing their dinners to school for the month of January and February.

Trusting that this will meet with your kindest approval."

Owing to Mrs Carlin's letter of the 29th., ultimo reaching this Office during my absence visiting the Reserves in this Agency, the matter could not be attended to earlier.

I recommend that I be authorized to purchase 1 case (24 Tins) of Drimilk for this School, and would appreciate an early reply, as the present supply is exhausted.

Sir:

I beg to advise that the well at the teacher's residence on the Moose Woods Sioux Reserve is going dry. Also that the cribbing therein is rotten from the top down to a depth of 10 to 15 feet, and the pump needs replacing, as the pump head is broken, the cylinder worn out, the pipes require re threading and the rods are badly bent.

To have this well cleaned out, deepened by ten feet, rotted cribbing renewed and a new pump installed, it will cost approximately as follows:

Labour cleaning well. $15.00
Deepening well 10 ft @ $1.00 10.00
Material for cribbing. 25.00
Pump for well. 30.00

Approximate total cost........... $80.00

It is possible that when the work of cleaning the well is commenced it will be discovered that the cribbing at the bottom of the well has commenced to rot. If such is the case, it would be more economical to dig a new well. Water should be found at a depth of 30 feet, and the cost of labour, material and new pump for same would cost approximately $110.00.

I recommend that authority be granted to allow an expenditure of approximately $110.00 to be used to the best advantage in procuring water for the teacher's residence and Indian Day School on this Reserve.

Your obedient servant,

Sir:

Reference: Agency letter 2578-6-94 July 8/37
References Dept. letter 109-11-5 July 28/37.

Well at Moose Woods Sioux Day School.

I beg to report as follows:

As the site on which the well at the Teacher's Residence on this Reserve is located is eighteen miles from the nearest owner of a well-boring machine, also as it was a small job, I was unable to get an experienced man to undertake this work until August the 29th, when Mr. Jamieson of Dundurn, Sask., agreed to do it.

On examination of the old well he would not agree to attempt to deepen it, as the cribbing therein was too rotten, therefore making it too dangerous to work in. He seemed confident of being able to secure a good supply of water at a depth of 30 feet. I therefore engaged him and agreed to pay him at the rate of $1.50 per foot for a 24 inch hole up to 30 feet deep, providing he found a good supply of water. If not, he would be paid $.85 per foot. These prices to include the wages of his helper, the use of his machine which is operated by horse power, also the board for himself, his helper and team.

On Sept. 3rd, Mr. Jamieson advised that he had gone down to a depth of 24 feet, at which point sand and water was encountered and he was unable to go deeper as he could not drive the well cribbing through it. Also that there was only 18 inches of water in the well and it would not come in fast enough to be of any use.

I was unable to visit this Reserve until yesterday, and before leaving that district I got in contact with a Mr. H. Owens, who lives adjacent to the Reserve. He submitted the following offer:

Salvage the cribbing in the dry hole. Hand-dig a four foot circular hole to a depth that will give a supply of water four feet deep every three hours, install the cribbing, make the rings which are to brace the cribbing every three feet; also install the frost-lid 10 feet down and a floor in the well; cement the top of the well and install the pump.

He will charge for this work at the rate of $1.50 per foot up to 30 feet. If found necessary to go further than 30 feet he will do so without further additional charge. He guarantees to provide the labor for a completed job at a cost not exceeding $45.00. In the event of a dry hole no charge will be made.

Mr. Owens seemed confident he would get a water supply at 30 or 35 feet.

The sum of $110.00 has been authorized to replace the broken pump in the well now going dry, also to dig a new well. Of this the following has been expended;

| Item                  | Cost   |
|-----------------------|--------|
| Pump and fixtures     | $20.00 |
| Lumber and wire       | $12.00 |
| Cement                | $1.50  |
| Hauling material      | $4.00  |
| 20 foot dry hole      | $85 cents |

Total: $57.90

If Mr. Owens can secure water at a depth of 30 feet a further expenditure of $45.00 for labor and approximately $35.00 for material will be required which would over-expend the $110.00 authorized by the sum of $28.00. In the event of a dry hole at 30 feet we would be within the amount authorized and would have $17.00 left to purchase more material.
Continuing letter No. 2855-6-94
Duck Lake, Sask., Sept. 22nd, 1937.

-- to go deeper at no additional cost for labor, unless water is found, and labor then would amount to $45.00

The old well that is almost dry has been supplying the water used for watering the milk cows at the Teacherage and for household purposes. The Indians on this Reserve were also using it for their household purposes as well as drinking water for their children while at School. Unless a further supply is found at the present site other wells will have to be dug for the use of these people.

I recommend that Mr. Owens offer be accepted and that I be authorized to expend $40.00 more than already authorized if found necessary to do so, in order to get a water supply.

An early reply would be appreciated as Mr. Owens will not undertake this work at the price mentioned if the ground becomes frozen.

Your Obedient Servant,

S.H. Simpson

Dear Sir:-

I beg to advise that the interior of the following Indian Day schools at the Duck Lake agency are badly in need of redecorating:

James Smith's south Day school; Requires to have all plaster work brushed and kalsomined and the floors and woodwork require painting.

James Smith's north Day school; Requires the same also repairs to the plaster work on the ceiling. The floor of the children's dining room is in places almost worn through, many of the boards being badly splintered making it difficult to scrub.

Moose Woods Day school; Requires to have all surfaces brushed before kalsomining and painting is done with the exception of the floor.

Two coats will be required both for kalsomining and painting in all three schools. Indian labor will be employed on all this work.

Dear Sir;

I beg to advise that in response to my report by Letter No. 2855, dated Sept. 22nd, last, in connection with procuring a well for the Moose Woods Whitecap Sioux Indian Day School the Department by letter No. 109-11-5, dated Oct. 5th, last, authorized an expenditure of $150.00 for this purpose.

Mr. Jamieson, of Dundurn, was first employed for this work. On Sept. 3rd, last, he reported he could not guarantee an adequate water supply in the 24 feet deep well he had dug on account of the nature of the sand. On October 12th I then requested Mr. R.E. Creelman of Saskatoon, who has the reputation of being one of the best well men in the district, to examine the work already done and let me have his advice on the matter.

He advised that he could procure a good water supply and would guarantee being able to do so providing a certain type of sand point was installed. I then employed Mr. Creelman to complete this work, which he agreed to have completed by November 10th, last.

On October 19th Mr. Creelman cleaned out the sand in the well to a depth of 26 feet and installed a 12 foot x 10 inch galvanized pipe which he gravel-packed.

Owing to not being able to procure the proper sand point locally when the work mentioned was completed Mr. Creelman moved his machinery to work in another part of the district, and was unable through an injury to his foot to return to the reserve to complete the work by the time agreed upon.

In June of this year water could not be pumped from the well as the old sand point which was temporarily installed would no longer work.

As water was badly required for the school children Teacher's residence, and the Indian families living nearby I had Mr. Creelman complete his contract.

The expenditures in this connection in 1937 are as follows:

The new sand point installed appears to be satisfactory, and an adequate supply of water is now being obtained.

I beg to request that the Department concur with my action in this matter and favorably consider payment of the attached account.

With reference to Departmental Letter No. 109-11-5, pertaining to new cook stove required for the Moose Woods Sioux Indian Day School, the following is a description of a stove that would suit the purpose for which it is required.--

Polished cast-iron cooking top; four eight inch and two four inch cooking covers; copper reservoir that holds four imperial gallons. Enclosed herewith please find Voucher No. 59 amounting to $26.93 covering a cot, mattress and pillow supplied for the new teacher at the Moose Woods Sioux Indian Day School.

This young man arrived at the Moose Woods Sioux Indian Day School from Toronto and did not have a bed of his own and was apparently under the impression that same would be supplied at the teacherage.

This school has been without a teacher since last June and it has been very difficult to obtain a teacher and it was thought best to obtain a bed for this man rather than discourage him by advising that he would have to obtain a bed for himself.

Under the circumstances I would recommend that the enclosed Voucher be paid and that the bed remain as a fixture of the Moose Woods Sioux School teacherage.

October 10th, 22

Reference to your No.305/14 A.of the 7th ultimo, instructing me to have a cottage erected on Woods Woods Sioux reserve near Dundurn, to accommodate the school teacher at that point.

I beg to report that the building has been erected and a good job has been done.

I quoted prices for the material required from local firms and purchased from the lowest tender.

The hauling of the material I had done by the Indians, allowing them 35¢ per Cwt., which I consider very reasonable, the distance being 22 miles over a very heavy road.

The hauling of sand and gravel for the foundation & chimney, 5 yards, I had hauled by Indians also, allowing them $6.00 per yard, the distance being 14 miles.

The specifications did not call for a cellar and as I considered one necessary for the keeping of vegetables in winter, I had a cellar 6x10x5 feet dug for which I allowed $5.00 to an Indian. This I had boarded up with Shipplap nailed to 2nd studding. The cellar is lit by a cellar sack which I had put in the foundation. I also had a small outer house (W.C.) built, the cost of the material for this and the cellar lining will be found on the statement for extra.

The labour I had done by Miners & Bell Contractors, who sent out one of their Foreman and other men for the following rates; Foreman 25¢ per hour, Carpenters 75¢, Carpenter's Helper 50¢, Brick Layer $1.15, Painters 75¢. This I considered the most satisfactory way as these men are accustomed to working together under their Foreman.

I am enclosing herewith accounts for material, labour and hauling, and trust same will meet with your approval.

Yours truly,

Sgd. C. Paul Schmidt
Indian Agent.

Dear Mr. Scott:

For twenty days in the month of October I was going carefully through the Indian missions in the western part of the diocese, and I desire to call your attention to my notes with a view to a request afterwards.

ISLAND LAKE.

About forty miles North by East of Onion Lake. A long beautiful lake full of islands, the greater part within the reserve.

They had 118 of population, but the flu of 1918 swept off forty-three, so that it left a very desolate band of 70 or so. Many of the houses are still standing deserted.

Now however they have a number of young children and total about 110. The reserve is completely isolated, very few people travel that way because there is nothing beyond them but one large and four or five little bands of Indians. No Bishop either Anglican or Roman had ever visited them before, and the only baptized children in the band belong to the Church of England.

The land is altogether too rough for agriculture and so they live a precarious life travelling round the settlements working during the summer months and fishing on their beautiful lake in the winter. But the provincial game laws are a great trouble to them. Their nets are small and in the winter the fish take to the deep water.

I held a long meeting with the Chief and others, and they very cordially agreed to the suggestion that they should put up a log building and mud it, while we would find the windows, shingles and floor, and then ask the Indian Department to give a qualified teacher for the six winter months.
Re Island Lake, Continued.

They seemed perfectly willing to do the work but they have absolutely no money, and nothing whatever is being done there in the way of farming instruction or uplift of any kind.

I earnestly beg of you on behalf of these people, the great majority of which are utterly pagan, to give us the appointment of a six winter months' teacher for this Reserve of Island Lake.

BIG ISLAND LAKE.

About fifty miles further north after crossing the Beaver River we came to Big Island Lake. Far larger than Island Lake probably thirty to thirty-five miles long and twelve miles wide, also filled with beautiful islands.

The Chief is dead but the son of the Chief gave us the names of about 100 people all told on the Reserve at the present time. There were either sixteen or eighteen houses built but they were going to build some more this winter. Here again the impression was, totally out of the world and forgotten.

The Indian Agent had helped them with a sawmill some time ago and there was abundance of lumber to be seen but there is little or nothing in the way of agriculture. The great majority are pagan, the few baptized Christians belonging to the Church of England. The suggestion of a school some time ago met with strenuous opposition from a handful of the "old men pagans", but this has died down and the younger men who have families are becoming quite anxious to have a school.

Here, as at Island Lake only a winter school could be operated for six months for the present at any rate because during the summer months the people clear off in all directions, presumably earning some money. They are quite willing to get out all the logs and put up a good log building if we would provide the windows, doors and they have plenty of lumber for floors etc.

They have a beautiful reserve every mile of which could be cultivated into beautiful farms, but I did not see a single place where there was any cultivation.
Re Big Island Lake. Continued.

The younger men however, are getting very anxious at their want of progress and would gladly receive the appointment of a teacher for the six winter months. In this reserve I should expect that to be changed into a full year teacher as the Indians begin to cultivate their own reserve.

Here again, I earnestly beg of you to let us do something and begin with the winter appointment of a six months teacher. In both cases it is too late to do anything this winter except get ready, but if you will promise us the appointment of two teachers for next winter, we will urge on the preparation of the two log buildings during this winter.

The other reserves in that district are not ripe for anything more than they have at the present time.

With kindest regards

Believe me to be

Yours very faithfully,

[Signature]

Duncan Scott, Esq.
Superintendent General
Dept. of Indian Affairs
Ottawa, Ont.

Sir,

We have been asking repeatedly, for the last years, for a Day-School to be opened on our Big Island Lake Reserve, in the Onion Lake Agency, but so far, we have received no answer of any kind.

May I, today, in the name of my Band, renew our request for a school to be opened in the nearest future?

We want this school to be put under the auspices of the Roman Catholic Church, because half of our population here are Catholics, only a couple of families being Anglicans, the rest being still pagans.

We have approached Mr. Charles Hebert, actually teaching at the Cold Lake Indian school, at Legoff, and he would be willing to be transferred to our new school, provided this transfer be proposed to him under advantageous terms. We know him favorably and we expect to get along well with him.

Of course the school we ask for would be a trial affair, and we would not expect your Department to go into heavy expenses for the erection of a school house and a teacher's residence. If you would apply the roofing, the flooring, the windows, nails, few rolls of building paper, ... the logs, labor, etc., could be supplied by ourselves.

We trust that you will give this, our request, your kindest attention, and that you will favor us with an early and favorable answer.

I remain,

Sir,

your most humble and obedient servant,

Joseph Bighood
Chief of the Big Island Lake Reserve
Onion Lake Agency.

At the meeting I explained to the Indians the situation with respect to a Day School for their reserve; and reminded them that they had frequently petitioned the Rev. E. Ahenakew for one to be run under the auspices of the Anglican Church; and told them that I had been instructed to stop any further work on the Roman Catholic building then in course of erection; and invited them to give me their views on the subject, and I would report whatever they had to say to the Department. Eleven adult male members of the band were present. They were unanimous in stating that they had never asked either the Anglicans or the Roman Catholics for a Church; but admitted that they had asked both the Rev. E. Ahenakew, of the Anglican Church, and the Rev. Father Balter, of the Roman Catholic Church, to build an Indian Day School for them. They added that they did not care which of the two denominations built the school, so long as they had one. They also told me that the priest visited them often during the past winter and on every occasion would ask them if they wanted a school to be built by the Roman Catholics; and that they gave him no answer until late in the Spring, when they told him they would consent to one being built, and they selected the site for it. They added that nothing was ever said to them about building a church. They also asked me to request the Department not to halt the work on the present building, which, although they realized it would be used also for church services, was intended, primarily, for an Indian Day School.

Whilst travelling around the reserve, and also at the Indian meeting, I took a religious census of the
band, which is, approximately, as follows:

I had heard, more than a month ago, from Father Balter, who is in charge of the R. C. Mission at Cold Lake, that the Roman Catholics intended to erect a building on the Bighead's Reserve, to be used as an Indian Day School; and that the Church Provincial, at Edmonton, was in correspondence with the Department in the matter; but, although I knew that the Rev. Father Balter was arranging with a sawyer in the vicinity of the reserve, for the purchase of lumber for this building, I did not know that building operations had actually commenced.

I may add that since my return from the Bighead's reserve, I have seen the Rev. E. Ahenakew and have explained to him the situation there. He seemed to feel that the Department may think he has misrepresented conditions at the reserve, whilst visiting at the Department; but he explained this to me by telling me that he had not then heard of the large number of children which has recently been baptised into the R. C. Church. I may say that I asked the Rev. Father Balter for a list of these children, which he gave me on my return from the Bighead's reserve, and which total 34; this number corresponds very closely to my census figures, which are 35.

Dear Sir:

With reference to the Big Island Lake Reserve, my Deputy informs me that the Church of England and the Roman Catholic Church have both requested a day school. Dear Archdeacon:

In the spring of 1929 the Indians of Big Head's Reserve (Big Island Lake), Onion Lake Agency petitioned for a C.of E. Day School. Most of them signed the petition the Chief's name leading the rest.

A month or two while in Ottawa I took up the matter with Mr. Ferrier at your request. Imagine my surprise when he took a letter from a file and told me he had had it from the chief of the reserve and a priest and that they were asking for an R.C. School. I was so offended at the duplicity of the Chief that I refrained from pushing the matter for the time being at least.

After this other petitions came to us from the fathers of the children of school age. When I was in Ottawa last September I again went in to see Mr. Ferrier about the question of having the school built. I understood Mr. Ferrier to be willing if a favorable report came from Mr. Turner, the Ind. Agent from Onion Lake.

The next thing I heard was that the R.C. Church had taken the law in their own hands and had started to build without first securing permission from the Dept. The building operations were stopped by Dr. Scott for the time being and that I believe is where the matter rests at present.

Mr. Turner had a meeting with the Indians and he tells me they were all willing that the R.C. building should go on and that they did not want it stopped. I have the highest opinion of Mr. Turner's integrity and would never think of questioning his word.

I was at Big Head's in January and in a meeting arranged by themselves and without any influence being brought to bear on them they signed the appended paper by putting their marks opposite their names. The Chief who did not sign but was present in the meeting said that if they could not get an R.C. School, he would be glad to see an Anglican school built instead.

This is brief is the history of the matter as I know it. My personal opinion is this—If the Dept. allows the R.C. building, which was started unlawfully, to be completed, then the question as to whether we are not losing out by punctiliously conforming, in all things, to the...
regulations of the Ind.Dept., may well be raised.

Yours very sincerely

Ed. Othenakew

I have the honour to submit the following report in reply to your letter of April 12th.

On January 10th last I visited Higham's reserve and inspected their day school. There were twenty children enrolled and fourteen in attendance. I only made slight reference to the school in my monthly report as we had on file a communication from the Department, No. 117-2-1 of November 30th, 1931, to the effect that the carrying on of a day school on this reserve was not authorized, and consequently class room material, etc., would not be supplied.

The school has been in operation since last November with an enrollment of twenty and an average attendance of fifteen, and in addition there are nine of school age who are not enrolled. Their teacher is Mrs. Hartman Martinson, who has no special qualifications. Mrs. Martinson is the daughter of Mr. Indian Agent Harris, First Nation, and received her education at that point.

The building is a frame structure 24' x 36', with 10' ceiling, gable roof, roofing paper, outside wall finished with lap siding and painted. Inside finish, building paper, unplastered. The school is facing east, with three windows on the south and two on the east.

The equipment is largely improvised, consisting of two blackboards, twelve homemade benches, old school books (second hand) slates, dishes for common use, one wash basin and water pail.

In addition there are two log buildings in the premises, viz., a three room dwelling for the teacher and a residence, five rooms, for the priest, Reverend Father Gauthier.

In my opinion a day school is very much indicated at this point, and at a meeting of these Indians I am requested to try find facilities for them the same assistance from the Department as was given to the Indians of Island Lake, a neighboring reserve, for their school.

Reverend Father Gauthier has been most active and has been doing good work among the Indians, and they have shown marked improvement since he has been with them. We have also heard of great assistance to us by co-operating in looking after the sick and destitute, and he informs me that Miss Jappan, who is living with the present school teacher and her husband, is a qualified school teacher, and is available to immediately replace Mrs. Martinson.

I have the honour to be,

Sir,

Your obedient servant,

Acting Indian Agent.

I wish however to bring to your attention the fact that the Rev. Father Gauthier has had a day school in operation for some time at Joseph Bigheads which is being operated by the Church. He has provided a frame building 24' x 24' with 10' walls and a rubberoid cottage roof. Thirty pupils are enrolled; eleven boys and nineteen girls; twenty-five attending regularly. Mrs. R. Memorandum:

Dr. McGill

In 1925, the Anglican Bishop of Saskatchewan requested the establishment of a day school on the Big Island Lake (Big Head) Reserve No. 134. No action was taken at that time. In March, 1929, the Chief of the Band requested that a day school be established, under the auspices of the Roman Catholic Church. At that time, the religious population of the Band was approximately as follows:

|                | Adults | Children |
|----------------|--------|----------|
| Church of England | -      | 6        |
| Roman Catholic   | -      | 16       |
| Pagan            | -      | 22       |

The local Indian Agent was requested to state if an undenominational day school would have any chance for success, as the Department would be unable to consider two day schools—one for Catholics and one for Protestants. He replied that this would be satisfactory to the Indians if they were left alone in the matter but that the Roman Catholic Church had been doing a lot of missionary work on this reserve and he felt confident that the authorities of that church would not be satisfied with an undenominational school.

In 1930, the Catholic Church authorities began the construction of a building for church and day school purposes. The Department, upon being advised, wired the Right Reverend O. Charlebois, O.M.I., Bishop of Keewatin, refusing approval for the construction of this building. In April, 1931, the Catholic Church applied for a site for a church and other buildings on the reserve, and, by P.C. 1935, of August 14, 1931, authority was given to lease 2.7 acres of land for mission purposes. A surrender of this land was obtained from the Indians of the Band. The Catholics have erected a church and also a school building—the latter being of frame construction, 24 ft. x 24 ft., with 10 ft. wall.

In November, 1931, the services of a teacher were obtained and the school opened. There is stated to be an enrollment of 30 pupils. The establishment of a school and the conduct of this activity has not been officially approved. Both His Lordship Bishop Charlebois and the Reverend Father Lejeunesse have visited the Department and strongly urged the recognition of the school and the providing of a teacher's salary and classroom equipment.

As we are preparing our Estimates at the present time, I should like to be advised if provision should be made for a teacher's salary—approximately $1,000. The Department has granted permission for the erection of a church and leased the site on which the school building has been erected, and, as there is need for a school on this reserve and the greater number of the Indians are Catholic, I shall be pleased to be advised if the Department will recognize this activity, under Catholic auspices, and provide a grant for a teacher's salary.

I have the honour to acknowledge receipt of your 115-2-1, of June 20th, with reference to a day school on Bighead's reserve, and in reply.

I would strongly recommend that a day school be established on this reserve as there are thirty children of school age in this band who should be getting proper tuition. The Reverend Father Gauthier has been operating a school at the Mission on his own since November, 1931, but it was poorly equipped and the teacher in charge was not qualified. The Indian Residential Schools at Onion Lake are full to capacity and these children could not be accommodated here at present. The Mission building which has been used for a school house is commodious, well built, and would be suitable for the purpose, and the equipment from the Cold Lake day school, which was closed last year, is available and could be easily transferred.

Regarding the denominational aspect of the school, the Bighead Indians are largely Roman Catholics and Pagans. There is the odd Anglican but they are very much in the minority. These Indians have been ministered to almost exclusively by the priest from Cold Lake since I came West in 1903. The neighboring reserve, Island Lake, has a C. of E. day school operating successfully since 1909. In my opinion the Roman Catholics have as good or even better claim to a day school at Bighead's as the C. of E. had to one at Island Lake.

I have the honour to be,

Sir,

Your obedient servant,

Level as it cannot stand like that any longer. How do you want the poor little Indian children to grow
strong and healthy on such a strong
ration as following and just during five

60 lbs. of meat of the time 40 lbs. bone. Also 20 lbs.
rice for the whole school. This is what they
get each month during five months. Judge if this

pupil receive 2 little Eskimo tea biscuits every

to notice the big amount of money spent
on the Boarding Schools compared with our
Day School. I do not think neither that
the results obtained in these big schools
are more favorable than ours. It seems
to me that the Day Schools have been

cost enormously less to operate. Our
pupils will succeed very likely as well

Our Day School pupils should be fed every

or two meals a day. It will be hard for the parents even to find a pail, box or paper to put the lunch in, if they had one. Many times children have come to school in the morning without breakfast. They entirely depend on their noon lunch in order to get a good meal. I wish that you would look into this matter as soon as possible and that our pupils be fed decently during the ten months that school is in operation. As I am much interested in the attendance of our young folks I am myself from my own pocket supplying the lunch for all the school children during the balance of the five months that the Board fails to give. Dear Sir:

I desire to acknowledge receipt of your letter of the 31st ultimo and to state, by way of comment, that I was somewhat disturbed to learn of the existing conditions in your district.

It has been the policy of the Department, in the past, to establish Indian day schools on reserves where home conditions were reasonably good and where an adequate food supply, sufficient to meet the needs of the children, was available. It would appear that provision has always been made, in residential schools, for orphan children and children from comparatively destitute homes. In view of the statements contained in your communication, it is just possible that we may have to seriously consider the advisability of transferring the pupils now in attendance at your school to one or more of the residential schools in the province of Saskatchewan.

The records here indicate that you were supplied with 950 lbs. of biscuits; 300 lbs. of beef; and 100 lbs. of rice, as a food ration for the pupils in attendance at your school, to cover a five month period. We have been assured, from the Indian Agent, that the beef supplied was of standard quality, and we know that the biscuits are highly nutritious. If, as you contend, however, a number of pupils reach school without breakfast, it is too much to expect that even the noonday lunch is sufficient in itself to maintain physical fitness. I notice in the reports, also, reference to the cultivation of a school garden. Has it been possible during the present year to obtain from this garden vegetables for

Mr. J. H. Lirette,
Teacher,
Big Island Lake Indian Day School,
Beacon Hill, Sask.
use in the preparation of the noon lunch?

Our experience here has been that, in the majority of schools where the noon lunch is supplied, it has not been necessary to provide for this lunch during the entire 10 month period. I am inclined to think that, in most cases, the pupils welcome an opportunity to return to their home at the noon hour. However, I am not sufficiently familiar with the conditions confronting you to state at this time exactly what our policy at your school should be.

I was gratified to learn that it is your intention to visit Ottawa during the holiday period. It is scarcely necessary to add that I shall be glad to meet you and discuss with you problems peculiar to your district at that time.

Dear Mr. Hoey:

As it is a very long time that I did not write to you re. Indian Welfare, I thought of writing a long letter. I think that you are now in a position to tell me about your plan, for an adequate follow-up system. I have greatly that idea at heart, since it seems ridiculous to spend so much money on young Indians which is contributing to a kind of fiasco. I am a great advocate for a genuine follow-up system. Our ancient pupils of Boarding Schools here, are the worst youngsters of the Reserve. Their little knowledge of English language makes them think...
that they are smarter than the other Indians on the Reserve. With their little dose of instruction which they cannot employ to good advantage as they do not continue to read nor write, making them worst by giving them chance to mix up with English speaking people, to frequent all the dances in the district, to sneak after moonshine and hooch. But a word, I am on the spot here and am able to judge these young people. Not a single one got married according to the law last year. There was all of them who lived quite a time with their future wives before being married legally. I have to be cold, reprimand them scare them in order to induce them to be married correctly. At present they are neither good Indians nor they do not live like the good White men. The trouble is often living too long to learn the White People ways, they are sent back home with the old folks who are dirty, poor, sloppy.
Lazy, stubborn, being pleased with their children's education for now their children are ashamed of them, to see them so filthy and backward. These young people coming home with nothing to do and nothing to work with. Parents have no cattle, no instruments, no wells, no good horses etc., etc.

They get disgusted and pass their time not at hunting deer or fishing but hunting women, young girls, gambling, drinking etc. Now Mr. Hay, I am not exaggerating just come here on our Reserve in the month of January or February you will find out if the Government is to be proud of its alumni! If you were to see the dwellings of our Indians and their belongings and think that these people are wards of the Canadian Govt. you would be ashamed as I am ashamed myself when White People pass through the Reserve and see that state of affairs! We have the finest forest of spruce on...
our Reserve lots going to waste by fire etc., and to see that there is not a single frame house on the entire Reserve. Somebody is to be blamed for this condition, but not myself. It is obvious that something must be done to put our Indians on their feet as self-supporting Indians instead of being liabilities. They should be assets to our country. I cannot see why this cannot be done. Indians way and sympathy seem to discourage the strongest will after a few years working for them. We are inclined to let everything go. But it should not be so. Everybody working with Indians should be convinced enough to keep to his duty and fulfill it at all cost, not to let loose the reins of these bronchos. Every strict control must be kept over them. It seems that they are left to themselves, they are not punished and they do according to their whims. I am suffering here on account of that lack of control. They build and act according
to their will not according to common sense and to their welfare I can do practically nothing as I am not booked up in my work. Not a single Indian was called up to work for war efforts. There are about 4 able men here on the Reserve. Talk about the poor women leading a filthy and lazy life. Nothing to do but near the whole day long except to boil tea, sweat out their tin pots etc., to make a little bannock by the fire place. Some material should be sent to them along with necessary tools in order that they could knit something for the soldiers. They should be busy and make money, but it is up to the Govt. to supply them means to work and to pay them for their work. This is very important. In the Onion Lake Agency there are too many small Reserves like here, Big Rock, and Lion's Head, Long Lake and Frog Lake. These have
no Farm Instructors and consequently somewhat neglected. Some of them should be put under some Farm Instructors and be started to improve. It is a great drawback to have so many small Reserves. As it is hard to grow them as they should but have a good strong Reserve consisting of at least two inhabitants, all if more the better it would be. In the best convenient place should be the school, church, hospital, store buildings, store, work shops for men and women, houses with gardens arranged. Each family should have about acres of private land and not too far away a big community hall for the welfare of the whole tribe. Every able man should work now and then at first time at this Community Farm. The Farm Instructor must be following up the Indians pretty near during the whole day. There should be a civil organization pretty near like in a College, chief councilors,
jury, police etc., a doubled cell prison for short infractions. I have assuming the Native School or matrons under care of competent women for the delinquent women. I cannot tell you all particulars in this letter, but any way you might get a little idea of my plan which I think will lead the Indians to be quickly self-supporting and adopt people of Canada. I am coming now back to the Board of Residential Schools for a follow-up system. So my opinion, the girls should be kept in the Boarding Schools until 18 years of age and be married then as soon as possible before they are contaminated. The young couples should be given a household outfit. A decent house, stove, utensils, etc., a good tract of land, horse harness, wagon, sheep, cows, pigs, chickens etc., etc. Food for wintering animals during winter if any. The old people must keep away from young. The overseer of the Reserve must follow them up closely and make himself obeyed.
Now, the tools that they were taught to work with at the Boarding School should be kept in the Blacksmith's shop and Carpenter's shop on the Reserve. To have tools only at the Boarding School and nothing (as it is the law now) on the Reserve seems absurd! You see that the Federal Govt. has to put up quite a sum of money, but you know that: One cannot do something with nothing. It is amazing the amount of money spent for Indians with no good results, around here anyway.

Now Mr. Henry if you need me here on this Reserve to make a trial for a follow-up system I am ready to help you, to cooperate with you and make the necessary experiments according to your dictates i.e., directions. I could be the organizer and overseer of the Reserve. If we never try something nothing would be done and large amounts of money spent needlessly. The state of affairs will remain unchanged if not bettered.
right away as the Indian population is increasing. Indians have a right for a new deal also! Since my years here in the West, schools have been operating for the supposed benefit of our Indians. I wonder how many are in a position now to take up their hands in jobs as agents, farm instructors, teachers etc etc. These jobs should gradually shift to the Indians themselves. Well, one thing is necessary for this. There should be in each province of the West one good High School (Boarding School) to take up boys and girls from the 6th grade to the College Curriculum. For the University course they should be following up the Public University in their own Province. Everything to be paid by the Indian Affairs Branch. One of the already existing Boarding School could be altered to receive somewhere like 200 pupils. Soon you would have well educated boys & girls who would be able to take up jobs belonging to them in the Indian Affairs Branch. How do...
The failure of the Indian Affairs Branch in the past in legislating for the Indians has been due to the omission to include the Indians himself. The Indians is a citizen of Canada without the rights, privileges, and duties of citizenship. He is discriminated against by Civil Service rules. He cannot obtain employment in the Indian Service. He is not taught enough to care for himself. Paternalism has discouraged him. He is in general irresponsible, intelligent, and willing to participate in self-government. No race of people can exist and make progress under such low social-economic conditions. Good health is necessary if any human being hopes to function in the community. The home atmosphere must be proper. Today many Indians are suffering from starvation and disease. Housing conditions are deplorable. The death rate is high. Educational progress cannot be realized under adverse economic
and social conditions. As a rule, seldom the Indians supply complete the 5th grade in the Elementary School. Handicrafts are neglected. Indians under proper conditions and favorable environment acts as any normal human being and with gratifying results. The problem to do is to make the Indians an intelligent citizen, law abiding and self-supporting. In regard to the Indians as he is today, the most pressing need is not that of his health which was sadly neglected, but his education which goes hardly beyond the 5th grade or taken into consideration vocational or professional training, and the lack of methods in showing him the habits of industry and economy. Like all problems it is easy to state but not so simple to provide the necessary solutions. In nearly every instance no one could for care to seek a solution. The main difficulty in the solution of the Indian question has been the failure to
recognize its magnitude and numerous complications. The Indian is asking what his future is to be at the hands of White men. The Indian is regarded as without ambition or initiative without any capacity or desire towards improvement; this is false! If it is necessary that this attitude of indifference on the part of the more powerful race must be changed, it must be replaced by an intense practical interest, sympathy, and co-operation between the White man and the Indian. This will afford him the opportunity and desire to better himself through a belief in his capacity of doing so. Poverty and unsatisfactory condition is the basis of Indian trouble today. The Indian did not appreciate the value of their land because of his lack of training in farming, the need for equipment, financial credit and general planning. Some Indians seem to be satisfied with their condition but they are not. He is asked to be placed with an existence in idleness and no responsibility. This attitude may be rather one of comfort.
discouragement. It is a type of Oriental fatalism and passive resistance due to hopelessness of the condition.

I sincerely hope that these lines will be accepted with the same spirit as they were written.

Yours Devotedly,

J. H. Liritte,
Teacher of Big Island Lake Indian Day School, Big Head Reserve, Onion Lake Agency, Redcon Hill, Sask.
Ottawa, April 20, 1945.

Dear Mr. Lirette:

I have for acknowledgment your letter of April 6 and have read over with a great deal of interest the information contained therein. I regret, however, that the limited time at my disposal has not enabled me to make a thorough study of the proposals you have submitted.

You will be interested to learn that a "follow-up" system was inaugurated by this Branch early in the year 1937. I am enclosing herewith, for your information, copy of a letter sent out to Indian agents at that time. The returns received at this date appear to be on the whole fairly satisfactory. The majority of the Indian residential school graduates appear to take good, immediately following their discharge from school. We do not appear, however, to have had a report from the Onion Lake Agency, and I am today communicating with the Indian agent in respect to this matter.

There is at this time an abundance of discarded military clothing and it is just possible that if the women on your reserve were organized they could remodel this clothing and thus make it very serviceable, not only for children, but for adults as well. Would it be possible for you to give a little direction to the organization of the women along the lines I have suggested?

There is also the matter of gardening. A supreme attempt should be put forth this year to interest our Indians in the production of foodstuffs, particularly vegetables. The Indians should look upon work of this kind as a patriotic duty, in view of the acute food shortage existing across the Dominion.

Yours very truly,

R. A. Hoey,
Supt. of Welfare & Training.

had help for many many years from Indian Affairs Branch by letting them have a farm instructor and other kinds of help that it should be our turn now to how provisions community.
