Dear Mr. Hoey:

The Indian Department school teachers are in a precarious condition compared to the Provincial school teachers. As you are aware, the Indian school teachers are so far apart, that it is very hard for us to get together and discuss our problems. We entirely depend on conditions as at present on the sense of justice and fair play of our officials in the Indian Affairs Branch. Few Indian School Teachers tried, by correspondence to have us join the Saskatchewan Teachers Federation but were unable by themselves to bring things about to a happy conclusion. Consequently I appeal to you to take this matter up please. Would you be kind enough to let me know what you have no plans to allow your school teachers to get
a pension when they reach old age. That is certainly a lacuna that should be remedied as soon as possible. The teachers in white communities have a pension scheme; they are paying at the present time 1/3 of their salary is deducted towards their superannuation. Once, a few years ago, I remember that two teachers were working out plans to have us join the Saskatchewan Teachers' Federation; but the objection was that the Federal Gov't was paying the teachers' salary. Maybe an understanding could be reached re payment to the Federation by the Federal Gov't, that would be satisfactory to all concerned. Thus we would belong to the Saskatchewan Teachers' Federation, mean the teachers of Saskatchewan, and be able to get a superannuation, if the Indian Affairs Branch does not do it.

I wish also the the Dept would make new regulations in order that the school teachers be considered as Civil Servants. Like we are at present, we are discriminated against other Gov't jobs within the Agency, we are on the same footing as the Indians. While the Agent, the Secretary, the Former Instructors are civil servants, we teachers are taking a back seat. We cannot be promoted to higher jobs in our Dept.
Even our salaries are always the same, but our families are increasing! In the Province of Alberta, teachers have their salaries increased at some fixed time. Most of all the other professions are asking for higher wages. My salary being insufficient I have to recourse to living alone and still that is not quite enough to pay for the expenses of my four children who are in boarding schools.

Please think over these reflections and work out something that will be satisfactory to your teaching profession. Your teachers are very interested in the welfare of the Indians. They stand as the spearhead of the army in combating ignorance, ill-mannered children and parents, filthy, diseased and ungrateful people. We surely deserve sympathy from our Officials.

Yours Devotedly, in the great human cause of the Indians' Welfare.

J. F. Lorette
Teacher of Indian Day School.
Ottawa, December 7, 1943.

Dear Sir:

I have for acknowledgment your letter of November 28, in which you discuss a superannuation fund that might be established for the benefit of Indian day school teachers.

I may state that the desirability of establishing such a fund has been discussed by the Minister of this Department and by the officials of this Branch on a number of occasions within the last five year period. The difficulties standing in the way of the establishment of such a fund appear to be, for the time being at least, insurmountable. I am enclosing herewith copy of a letter recently sent forward by me to Mr. Jos. Trohak, of Arbury, Sask. The subject matter of this letter, you will note, is self-explanatory. I might add that in my judgment there is not even a remote possibility of the establishment of such a fund at any time during the years immediately ahead of us. I make this statement, being aware that you have four children to support. In view of this fact, it is just possible that you may desire to seek a position in one of the provincial schools.

Yours truly,

R. A. Hoey,
Supt. of Welfare & Training.

Dear Father Plourde:

Mr. J.H. Lirette was appointed teacher of the Big Island Lake School in the Onion Lake Agency on September 1, 1935. His appointment at that time was recommended by Very Reverend U. Dear Mr. Packman:

You asked for a few more accounts in a second, which I will try to do.

When I put my order in for a bicycle I mentioned to the priest that I hoped I would receive it soon. He was horrified that a girl should ride a bike, and said I was not to ride it on the reserve as it set a very bad example.

He wished to teach at least half an hour of catechism every day, fifteen minutes of Cree and Cree syllables, in addition to choir practise, all in school hours. I was to see that the children attended Vespers every night from seven to eight. Of course I was to be there. This was especially hard when on Saturday I would go home or to some friend's. I also was trying to take my Grade Eleven and trying not to let it interfere with my school work.

He, himself, would come over for an hour or so in the evening, to talk, but figured whoever else might come, it was wrong. He always wanted to start a credit union and a co-op store for the children. I do not believe this is the best way of teaching. He always wanted me to teach against Socialism. These Indians are a backward race and first they must know what it is before you can say it is wrong.

Hoping this is sufficient information for you.

I remain,

Yours truly,

Dear Mr. Packman:

During the past term many difficulties have arisen, as it seems the priest was allowed to enter and teach the Catholic children catechism and leaving the others with nothing to do, at any period of time suitable to him each day. He also wished to teach Cree and Cree syllables in school. High Mass was conducted at the Church every first Friday of the month, and also any other day he cared to have it. He expected the children to attend, although it was in school hours. When I was opposed to this, he began to make trouble.

I was light housekeeping in the small house at the school. He was opposed to my having Protestant visitors as he claimed it was a bad example. He also did not approve of Catholic visitors. One Sunday a Catholic family came to visit and stayed to dine. He went to their home at a later date and told them they had no business bothering me. This happened in many different cases. At another time two young men were passing and stopped to say "Hello". As I had my supper prepared I asked them to join me. They left soon after as I went to Evening Prayer at seven, and they left before, but this, he claimed, was disrespectful behavior, in spite of the fact I had gone through school with them.

He also was opposed to theatres, playing sports in public, or dancing. I do not make a practice of going school nights, as I have my weekends.

I have tried to follow the Curriculum as closely as possible but it is hard to do with these others in my path always.

With these obstacles in my way I feel I cannot complete my duties with complete satisfaction, so I am resigning.

Yours truly,

(Miss) Gertrude Alice Marie Lepine.

Previous to visiting her school I was surprised to find that one so poorly qualified had been engaged, but I was also surprised when I visited the school to find that she was doing a better than average job with very backward Indian children, notwithstanding the fact that she had received no teacher training, in fact I would not hesitate to say that she was doing a remarkably good job. The children were bright and quick with their answers and were speaking English quite well after having made practically no progress whatever with the previous teacher, a Mr. Lirette.

I am not urging that Miss Lepine should reconsider her resignation as I think it was a mistake to engage her in the first place knowing she had no training for the work. However, I must point out very emphatically that if and when another teacher is appointed to that school there must be a more thorough understanding between the Superintendent, the teacher, and the Missionary as to their relationship toward each other and the relationship of the work of each to the work of the other.

I am sure we will never get a satisfactory teacher to remain at that school subject to continuous criticism and interference by the Missionary. While I heartily approve of the Missionary being permitted to give some religious teaching to the school children it should not be carried to a point where a considerable part of the teaching week is devoted to religious teaching.

Our Indian day schools in this.......
Our Indian day schools in this province have been severely criticised by some of the provincial authorities and I am sure that if Miss Lepine's story reached some of them the Department would be placed in a very difficult position.

J.P.B. Ostrander,
Regional Supervisor of Indian Agencies,
Saskatchewan.

I appreciate the frankness of your letter and also the attached correspondence from Mr. Packman and Miss Lepine.

I am today writing to Father Plourde concerning the actions of the Missionary on this Reserve as mentioned in this correspondence. July 19, 1948.

Dear Father Plourde:

Big Island Lake, Saskatchewan.

You will recall that I discussed with you and Reverend Father Provincial a rather strained relationship which exists between the teacher and the Missionary of the above Reserve.

Apparently Miss Lepine is making an honest attempt, in spite of her lack of qualifications, to do a good job as teacher at this school. In fact, we have had several comments that the pupils are making better progress under her than they were under Mr. Lirette.

Recent correspondence indicates that the Missionary has been unduly critical of Miss Lepine's work in and out of the school. Extract from recent letters of Miss Lepine's make the following points:

"When I put my order in for a bicycle I mentioned to the priest that I hoped I would receive it soon. He was horrified that a girl should ride a bike, and said I was not to ride it on the reserve as it set a very bad example.

He wished to teach at least half an hour of catechism every day, fifteen minutes of Cree and Cree syllables, in addition to choir practise, all in school hours. I was to see that the children attended Vespers every night from seven to eight. Of course, I was to be there. This was especially hard when on Saturday I would go home or to some friend's. I also was trying to take my Grade Eleven and trying not to let it interfere with my school work."
He, himself, would come over for an hour or so in the evening, to talk, but figured whoever else might come, it was wrong. He always wanted to start a credit union and co-op store for the children. I do not believe this is the best way of teaching. He always wanted me to teach against Socialism. These Indians are a backward race and first they must know what it is before you can say it is wrong.

"I was light housekeeping in the small house at the school. He was opposed to my having Protestant visitors as he claimed it was a bad example. He also did not approve of Catholic visitors. One Sunday a Catholic family came to visit and stayed to dine. He went to their home at a later date and told them they had no business bothering me. This happened in many different cases. At another time two young men were passing and stopped to say "Hello". As I had my supper prepared I asked them to join me. They left soon after as I went to Evening Prayer at seven, and they left before, but this, he claimed was disgraceful behavior, in spite of the fact I had gone through school with them.

He also was opposed to theatres, playing sports in public, or dancing. I do not make a practice of going school nights, as I have my week ends".

"As for my problems with the priest, it would be too difficult to explain in a letter. I try to do my best in teaching. He objects to me going to dances (which I go to once in a while on a Friday) to my friends and everything else that he can find fault with or imagine.

He says he'll see that I get fired. The way things stand now, I don't care, but I wanted to warn you ahead of time".

Yours sincerely,

Bernard F. Neary,
Supt. of Indian Education.

Rev. J.O. Plourde, O.M.I.,
Ottawa University,
Laurier Avenue East,
Ottawa.

Extract from the Quarterly report of the Meadow Lake Indian Agency for the period ending March 31st, 1949.

Education

In visiting the Day School at Bighead Reserve I was greatly impressed with the work of the present teacher, Miss G. Lepine. She is doing a splendid job and has the confidence of all the Indians on the Reserve. While this lady has not all the qualifications necessary to be known as a qualified teacher yet on every hand her work is so outstanding due to her natural ability that I would recommend that she be retained in this work. Previous reports have indicated that she and the missionary on this reserve are not co-operating to the fullest. For that reason she is definite in saying that she will not continue teaching in that school. My investigation to date would prove that no blame can be attached to Miss Lepine in this matter. Should she be moved, I would strongly recommend that consideration be given to her appointment in some other Indian School.

Big Island Lake Indian Day School

Dear Mr. Ostrander:

I have discussed the general situation at this school with Father Flourde who has discussed it with Father Provincial. It has been decided to watch carefully how the missionary gets along with the new teacher, Miss Forcier. I would ask you to advise the local superintendent to report on any similar friction arising as happened with Miss Lepine. If such trouble arises, then it is obvious that the missionary is a most difficult man with whom to work, and the necessary action can be taken to request a transfer.

As I indicated above, we are quite prepared to accept Miss Forcier's application, and she will be classified as a Grade I teacher at a starting salary of $102.00 a teaching month. When I hear further from you, I will send her the usual official letter of appointment.

Father Flourde suggested, and I agree with him, that, if possible, she should take a housekeeper to the school with her. If she has a younger sister or an aunt or cousin who could stay with her, I think it would be to the benefit of all concerned. I would like to have Mr. Kearns available for use in a very isolated school and have written to him about such a post. If Miss Forcier is available for Big Island Lake, then we will consider her application accepted.

Bernard F. Neary,
Superintendent of Education.

Big Island Lake Pay School

Salary Payments
Ottawa, October 25, 1934.

Sir:

I have to refer to your letter dated August 16th last, recommending that a day school be established on Big Head Reserve, as there are 30 children of school age who should be receiving an education.

In this connection I have to advise you that the Department will assume responsibility for the expenses in carrying on the work at this school as from January first, 1935. We will be responsible for teacher's salary, classroom equipment and reasonable expenses for fuel.

It is understood that school will be conducted in the mission house - a building of frame construction, 24 ft. x 24 ft., with 10 ft. wall. You may arrange for the transfer of desks and any equipment that would be serviceable from the Cold Lake Day School and have the Big Head classroom ready for use by the date above mentioned. Should any additional classroom equipment be required, please forward a requisition.

Regarding the services of a teacher, Mrs. E. Grey, Onoway, Alberta, is available. Mrs. Grey holds a first class Alberta professional certificate and has had several years' experience as a teacher. The Department approves of her appointment as from the first of January, next, with salary at the rate of $90.00 per teaching month.

Please inform Mrs. Grey accordingly and arrange with her to take up duties on or about the date mentioned. I would request, also, that you inform Rev. Father Gauthier, the missionary. This school will be conducted under the auspices of the Roman Catholic Church, as it is noted you state the Indians on the reserve are largely of that faith and pagan. Please advise the Department if Mrs. Grey accepts.

I would request that you advise the Department the official name which you would recommend be given this school. Should it be known as "Big Head" or Big Island Lake" Day School?

Your obedient servant,

T. R. L. MacInnes,
Acting Secretary.

Indian Agent,

Dear Sir,

The following is an extract from a letter recently received by the Department:

"Biscuits alone have been sent in September and October. Besides, $3.50 for meat is allowed per month during the winter months. You will admit that such an allowance is rather meagre. The Missionary has heretofore borne the expenses and this seems to me unreasonable not to say unjust. The children need more dishes for their lunch (kitchen utensils) and also play games."

In connection with the above, our file shows that $3.50 a month was allowed last year but you have not yet applied for any authority to expend this amount during the current year. I would again point out that a request for authority to expend amounts for midday meal purposes should be forwarded to the Department early in September of each year in order that the matter may receive our consideration.

Please let me know if you consider $3.50 a month is sufficient to allow for midday meal purposes at the Big Island Lake School in view of the fact that the Department has already supplied biscuits.

You might, also, let me know what amount the missionary has expended for midday meal purposes.

If more kitchen utensils are required for serving the midday lunch, a request for the purchase of same should be forwarded to us. No such articles have previously been refused. Please give this matter your immediate attention.

Yours truly,

A. F. MacKenzie.

Sir,

I have the honour to acknowledge receipt of your 115-2-5, of the 7th ultimo, with reference to the Big Island Lake Indian Day School.

I visited this school on December 17th, and the Missionary, Reverend Father Gauthier, was absent. Consequently, I did not get the information requested regarding the amount expended by him for the mid-day meals.

In reply to the second paragraph of your letter Authority was asked for on September 19th, and received on September 25th in your 115-5-5, of that date, to purchase the necessary beef for day schools. The maximum amount of beef allowed monthly, viz. 50 lbs. was provided for this school.

As stated, the mid-day meal consists of biscuits and beef in the form of a stew. This gives them a little over two ounces of beef each, in addition to soup and a full ration of biscuits. This ration has sufficed in the past and is exactly the same as our other day schools are receiving. Rice added to the soup would improve it and I estimated for rice for this purpose but did not receive it. We received 800 lbs only, for all purposes in the Agency.

Re kitchen utensils. I checked these over on my last visit and found sufficient plates, cups, knives, etc., for fifteen pupils, but the attendance has increased to eighteen, with twenty enrolled. The following is requested by the teacher and I would be pleased to receive authority to purchase them:

6 Plates
6 Cups
5 Window Shades
1 pr. Barber's Scissors
1 Barber's Comb and Barber's Clippers
1 Dust Pan and 1 Water Pail
1 Pot for boiling meat.

When Mr. Lirette
When Mr. Lirette, the teacher, started his duties I requested him to forward a complete list of what was required in this line, and the list he forwarded was incomplete. I procured what was then asked for, amounting to $12.65, on the Department's authority of August 15th. As previously stated, rice would improve the mid-day meal, and I would recommend that it be provided for the schools. Fifty pounds each was the quantity asked for.

At the conclusion of the winter months beef will not be available, and something more than dry biscuits will be required. Dried milk has been tried and the children do not like it. Whole milk is not available, and the best substitute, in my opinion, would be cocoa.

I have the honour to be,

Sir,
Your obedient servant,

J. T. Hill,
Indian Agent.

The Secretary,

Ottawa, January 30th, 1936.

Dear Sir,

With reference to your letter of the 13th instant, you may purchase the quantity of rice which you consider necessary for midday meal purposes at the Indian day schools in your agency. It is understood, of course, that the soup should only be served until the end of March. (See official letter of September 25th, 1935).

You may, also, purchase the following articles:

- 6 plates
- 6 cups
- 5 window shades
- 1 pr. barber's scissors
- 1 barber's comb
- 1 barber's clippers
- 1 dust pan
- 1 water pail
- 1 pot

Owing to lack of funds, the Department has not been authorizing midday meals during the fine weather and, under these circumstances, the Department is not prepared to authorize the purchase of cocoa to be used after the end of March.

If you refer to official letter of the 7th ultimo, you will note that the Department asked what amount the missionary has expended for midday meal purposes. Did you make any inquiries in this regard and, if so, what information did you receive?

Yours truly,

A. F. Mackenzie,
Secretary.

Dear Sir,

The Department is in receipt of a letter from the teacher of the Big Island Lake Indian Day School, in which he complains of the quantity of food allowed for midday meal purposes and, also, regarding the quality of the meat that has been furnished the school during the past winter.

Our records show that 300 lbs. of meat; 100 lbs. of rice and 950 lbs. of biscuits have been supplied to the Big Island Lake School. This would appear adequate for an average attendance of thirteen (13) children during the past two quarters.

The teacher also states that many of the children are without proper clothing. If conditions on this reserve are as bad as the teacher states, it may be necessary to consider placing a number of them from the poorer families in a residential school.

Please interview the teacher and let me have a complete report in connection with conditions at Big Island Lake.

Sir,

I have the honour to acknowledge receipt of your 115-2-5, of the 8th ultimo, with reference to the Big Island Lake Indian Day School.

Sir,

I have the honour to submit the following with reference to the mid-day meal supplied the children attending the four Indian day schools where there is a total enrolment of eighty.

At present it consists of beef and biscuits. Dry milk was supplied for a time and dropped, as it did not prove very satisfactory, but no substitute was provided. I would suggest that rice and cocoa be added to the present menu. These could be provided at a monthly cost of eight dollars, or an average of two dollars per school per month. The monthly requirement in rice and cocoa would be 80 and 16 pounds respectively.

Another great improvement, as I see it if funds will permit, would be to make the improved mid-day meal continuous throughout the teaching year, instead of five months as at present. A continuous, improved mid-day meal, together with the assistance given in clothing, will prove a great incentive in better attendance, and will place the day school on a basis where the residential school will not be a competitor as it is at present.

I have the honour to be,

Sir,
Your obedient servant,

J. T. Hill,
Indian Agent.

Sir,

I have the honour to refer to two items on page 7, of our 1939-1940 estimates, viz., towelling and soap for Indian Day Schools.

These will be required at the beginning of the school year, September 1st, and I would be pleased to receive authority to purchase them.

Beef, rice and cocoa, will also be required for the mid-day meals. Provision was made in the estimates for a mid-day meal throughout the entire school year, instead of for five or six months as in previous years. I would strongly recommend this if it can be arranged, as there is always a falling off in attendance when the serving of the meal terminates on April 1st or May 1st as previously. May and June, especially June, are very important months in the school year, as it is in June that exams are held and promotions made. You will readily understand that non-attendance at this period seriously interferes with the advancement of the pupils and the work of the teacher.

I have the honour to be,

Sir,
Your obedient servant,

J. T. Hill,
Indian Agent.

The Secretary,
Indian Affairs Branch,
Department of Mines and Resources,
Ottawa.
Dear Sir:

I desire to acknowledge receipt of your letter of the 11th instant and to state that you are authorized to purchase the towelling and soap necessary for use at the Indian day schools of your Agency.

I hesitate, at this moment, to issue authority for the purchase of supplies necessary to provide a noonday lunch at these schools. The records here indicate that biscuits have been already purchased for these schools and no doubt these biscuits have been delivered at this date.

Mr. Phelan, Chief of the Training Division, is at present in the Prairie Provinces and will review with Dr. Robertson the whole question of midday lunches at Indian schools. I agree with you that these lunches have a tendency to increase the attendance at the schools, and, in addition to this, contribute substantially to the health of the pupils. The preparation and serving of the lunch, however, unless carefully supervised, can result in the loss of very valuable time and in a great waste of material. Nearly everything depends upon the honesty and conscientiousness of the teacher in charge. It must always be kept in mind that our schools are not welfare institutions but are established and maintained for the instruction of the Indians. However, I shall be glad to discuss this matter with Mr. Phelan and communicate with you later.

Yours truly,

J. T. Hill, Esq.,
Indian Agent,
Onion Lake, Sask.

R. A. Hoey,
Supt. of Welfare & Training.

Sir:

I have the honour to refer to page 7 of the 1940-1941 estimates, viz., provision for mid-day meals for the children attending the four Indian Day Schools in this Agency.

I would be pleased to receive authority to provide supplies for these meals beginning October 1st, and continuing throughout the school term if possible, at an average cost of approximately $6.00 per month for each school, i.e., not exceeding $24.00 per month for the four schools. Only articles absolutely necessary, beef (if available) rice, cocoa and sugar, in the quantities required for each school would be purchased. The school biscuits have not yet been received.

I have the honour to be,

Sir,
Your obedient servant,

Donald H. Cameron,
Clerk in Charge.

The Secretary,
Indian Affairs Branch,

Ottawa.
Ottawa,
September 24, 1940.

Dear Sir:

With reference to your letter of the 14th instant the Department will allow, for the period November 1, 1940, to April 30, 1941, an amount not exceeding $6.00 a month for each of the 4 schools in the Onion Lake Agency in order to permit you to purchase the articles required to supply a midday lunch.

As you are aware our funds this year are limited and the above amount is the total that we can allow.

Yours truly,

R.A. Hoey,
Supt. of Welfare & Training.

Mr. D. H. Cameron,
Clerk in Charge,
Indian Agency,
Onion Lake, Sask.

Sir,

I have the honour to refer to page 7 of our 1941-42 estimates, viz., provision for mid-day meals for the children attending the four Indian Day Schools in this Agency.

Last year these were provided for the period - November 1 to April 30 - at an average cost of $36.00 for each school. This year, owing to higher costs prevailing, especially for meat, I would respectfully request authority to expend an average of approximately $42.00 for each school for the purchase of beef, rice, cocoa and sugar. These will be supplemented with vegetables from the school gardens.

If the Department is supplying biscuits to the schools this year I would be pleased to receive 1000 pounds to divide among the four schools. These could all be shipped to Frenchman Butte, Sask.

I have the honour to be,
Sir,
Your obedient servant,

Donald H. Cameron,
Indian Agent.

The Secretary,

Ottawa.
Ottawa,
September 24, 1941.

Dear Sir:

With reference to your letter of the 13th instant, regarding midday meals at the four Indian day schools in the Onion Lake Agency, funds at our disposal will only permit our allowing the same amount as last year and consequently, for the period November 1, 1941, to April 30, 1942, an amount not exceeding $6.00 a month for each of the four schools may be expended in the purchase of articles required to supply a midday lunch.

Yours truly,

R.A. Hoey,
Supt. of Welfare & Training.

Mr. D.H. Cameron,
Indian Agent,
Onion Lake, Sask.

May I refer to the matter of rental for the building used as teacher's residence and day school, on the Bighead Indian Reserve, in this Agency.

For many years prior to 1944 the Department paid a quarterly rental to the R.C. Church Authorities for the two buildings then used - Teacher's House and Day School. The school (Big Island Lake Indian Day School) was closed for a year and re-opened in November, 1945. Since then, in so far as I am aware, no rent has been paid. I referred to the matter once but have had no instructions as yet. At the time of Mr. Doucette's recent visit to Onion Lake I mentioned the subject to him, perhaps he will recall.

It should be noted that since the re-opening of the School in 1945, only one building has been used for school purposes - the building formerly used as the teacher's residence. This is because the teacher, Mr. J.R. Lirette, does not require the whole building now for living purposes as he has not his family with him.

May I request early instructions in the matter.

Donald H. Cameron,
Indian Agent.
Ottawa, 6 December 1946.

Mr. D.H. Cameron, Indian Agent,

You may submit a voucher for the amount due at this rate from Nov. 1, 1945 to December 31, 1946. In issuing the voucher you should refer to the school as "Big Island Lake Indian Day School."

Bernard F. Neary,

Duck Lake, Sask., November 1st, 1937

Sir;

I beg to report that while I was visiting the Kinistino Reserve on the 29th and 30th ultimo I noticed that a coal burning furnace had been shipped by the Winnipeg Paint and Glass Co., Winnipeg, to this Reserve to be installed in the new Indian Day School which is now under construction there.

This furnace is a straight coal burner, and the fire-box therein is so small that it would be impossible to heat the building by burning wood, which should be used for this purpose as there is at present an abundant supply of both dry and green wood on the Reserve. It could be supplied by the Indians at a cost of from $1.50 to $2.50 per cord, and would be a means of them receiving a revenue therefrom.

If this furnace is installed the Indians will be deprived of this revenue and the Department will be under considerable expense for many years by burning coal, as it will have to be hauled from 18 to 24 miles from the Railway to the Reserve, and would cost from $12 to $15.00 per ton delivered.

I was given to understand that the building would be ready for installation of the furnace by the 10th or 14th instant.

I would recommend that a wood-burning furnace with a fire-box large enough to take a four or five foot length of wood be shipped at once, and that the furnace now at the School be returned.

Your Obedient Servant,

S.H. Simpson,
Indian Agent.

The Secretary,

Memorandum: Mr. Miller.

Re: Kinistino Indian Day School.

With reference to the heating system at the above school it has been brought to our attention by the Indian Agent that a straight coal burning, hot air furnace has been supplied.

As there is an abundant supply of wood on the reserve which can be supplied by the Indians, and which would be a means of providing a revenue for them, it would be desirable to replace same with a wood burning furnace.

I would therefore request that a wood burning furnace, with a fire box large enough to take a three foot length of wood, be ordered and that the furnace now at the school be returned.

It is understood that the school building will be ready for the installation of this furnace by the 10th to the 14th instant.

I would appreciate if you would arrange to have this change attended to.

Dear Mr. Christianson:-

In a conversation with one of the men connected with the building of the school at Kinistino Reserve I was informed that owing to the way the specifications for the lumber was worded, the contractors could have supplied very inferior lumber without our being able to reject it. From what he said I would judge that the grading of lumber differs in the West from that of the East.

I am not writing this as a protest but in view of the fact that all the buying is to be done in Ottawa, it is a matter that I think should be looked into. As you are familiar with western lumber grades I am drawing it to your attention.

Yours truly,

Memorandum:

Dr. McGill

Re: New Day School, Kinistino Indian Reserve, Sask.

Final accounts have been received from Mr. G.H.L. Dempster in connection with the building of the above school showing that the total cost during the present fiscal year amounts to $4,961.00.

The amount provided in the Estimates for this project was $4,700.00 and the remaining $261.00 will be provided by a transfer from unexpended monies from Project No. 3.

The only work left uncompleted due to weather conditions is exterior paint work comprising staining the roof, painting the finishing coat on the outside of school building and two coat painting the privies. It is estimated that a sum of $50.00 will complete this work to and after March 31st next.

I would be glad if you could arrange to have this amount provided under the 1938-39 Estimates.

Director.

Duck Lake, Sask., February 21st, 1938

Dear Sir:

In reference to the third paragraph of Departmental letter No. 109-6-5, dated the 7th instant, pertaining to bookcases for the Kinistino Day School, I find that, upon enquiry there are no Indians on this Reserve who can build cupboards suitable for the purpose required. Mr. Gardner, the Teacher, also informs me that he has not had sufficient experience in carpentry work to undertake building a cupboard.

While at this School on the 17th and 18th instant, I found that the following items are required in addition to the above mentioned:

Kitchen cupboard for dishes, cooking utensils, etc.,
Wash-Stands (2)
Dining room table,
Dining room benches.

Plain lumber can be purchased and the work done at the School by a local carpenter much more cheaply than purchasing the articles ready-made.

As the cupboards will have to be built against the inside walls of the School it will be necessary that this work be done right at the School. Owing to the cost of travelling at this time of year I recommend that this work be left until the roads are passable next Spring.

Temporary arrangements for a dining-room table, benches and wash-stand are made and will suit the purpose for the time being.

Your Obedient Servant,

S.H. Simpson,
Indian Agent.

Duck Lake, Sask., April 6th, 1938

Dear Sir;

As requested by Departmental Letter No. 109-6-5, dated February 28th, last, I beg to report as follows re. additional articles required for the new Indian Day School on the Kinistino Reserve:

Cupboard for School books, Stationery, Etc.,
Cupboard for dishes, cooking utensils, Etc.,
Washstands (2),
Dining room table,
Dining room benches (2).

Material can be purchased and made up into these articles by employing a local carpenter at a cost of approximately $16.00 for material and $18.00 for labor.

The cupboards are to be built against the inside walls of the School. It will, therefore, be necessary to have the work done there.

I have been given to understand that Mr. Alex. Fraser, of Humboldt, who was foreman in charge of the construction of the School building there last Fall, will be returning to the reserve this Spring to complete the painting of this building. If so, he could be employed to build the cupboards, stands, table and benches while there for about $5.00 less than the price already quoted, as there is no carpenter living near the reserve an extra $5.00 has been allowed for this work to cover expenses in travelling to and from the School.

Form No. 37½ in Triplicate, listing the material required for this work is enclosed herewith.

Your Obedient Servant,

S.H. Simpson,
Indian Agent.

Dear Sir,

Ref: My letter No. 40-15-91, Apr. 6/38.
Ref: Dept'l. letter 109-6-5, Apr. 12/38.

I beg to advise that Mr. Alex. Fraser of Humboldt was expected to return to the Kinistino Reserve last Spring or Summer to complete the painting of the new Day School there, and had agreed to build the necessary cupboards, wash-stands, tables and benches for this school at a cost of $13.00. Mr. B.G. Willis of Humboldt was employed to complete the painting of the school. He was unable to build the cupboards, and as Mr. Fraser was unable to come before the school opened on September 1st it was necessary to employ someone else to do the work.

The nearest point at which a carpenter could be obtained to do this work was at Star City, a distance of 22 miles from the reserve. Owing to the distance that had to be travelled I was unable to get the work done at a cost of less than $18.00.

In view of these circumstances I beg to request that the Department will favorably consider payment of the attached Voucher No. 412, amounting to $18.00, in favor of Mr. B.C. O'Connor, Star City, Sask.

Your obedient Servant,

S.H. Simpson,

Dear Sir:

I beg to attach requisitions for food supplies for the mid-day meal, Day Schools in the Duck Lake Agency.

I would point out that during the past school year the Department granted the sum of $50.00 each for these schools to be expended for the purpose just mentioned. At the end of the school term the Kinistino School, which was closed this Spring owing to an epidemic of flu, only used $31.00. The Fort a la Corne South School had an unexpended balance of $4.60. The other three schools used the amounts allotted to them.

I might also say that a close check is being kept on supplies provided for these meals, each school submitting a monthly report on the supplies received, used, and remaining on hand.

The supplies on these requisitions, with the exception of biscuits, have never been provided heretofore. They are to be used principally for the making of biscuits, bread and dumplings, with a view to trying to do away with the supplying of school biscuits.

With regard to the school biscuits supplied, I have discussed this matter with our teachers and agents. The general opinion seems to be that for the amount of money expended on biscuits, a more adequate meal could be supplied and a considerable saving effected. These schools are willing to try this out this season and I would recommend the request be allowed. I would also point out that it gives our teachers an opportunity to instruct the children in baking and cooking. It is, in my opinion, very important that these girls should be taught how to bake bread and that every effort should be used to get the Indians to abandon the making of bannock instead of raised bread, as not only is the raised bread preferable from the health point of view, but it would also greatly reduce the flour requirements.

Yours truly,

Thos. Robertson,
Inspector of Indian Agencies,
Saskatchewan.

The Secretary,
Indian Affairs Branch, Ottawa.

Ottawa,
August 8, 1939.

Dear Sir:

I am in receipt of your letter of the 29th ultimo with reference to the midday meal supplies at the day schools in the Duck Lake Agency.

I note that the requisitions which you forwarded requested supplies to be used in place of biscuits.

In this regard I may say that the biscuits have already been ordered and will reach the respective schools in the near future. Under these circumstances the items mentioned on the requisition forwarded with your letter of the 29th ultimo are not being ordered.

Mr. Phelan, Chief of the Training Division, will be returning East about August 24 and will stop off for a day in Regina in order to meet you and at that time you might discuss with him the whole question of midday meals at the schools in Saskatchewan.

Yours truly,

R. A. Hoey,
Supt. of Welfare & Training.

Dr. Thos. Robertson,
Inspector of Indian Agencies,

I beg to enclose herewith Form #37 in triplicate listing materials required for the Kinistino Day School Building.

The basement of this school is used as a kitchen and dining room for the pupils of the school. The inside cement walls require finishing in order that they may be kept sanitary. Paint has been requisitioned for this purpose. It is considered that by using paint instead of Kalsomine it will permit keeping the walls clean by having them washed as they require it.

Screen windows were not provided when the school was constructed. Materials have been listed to make the screens required.

There is no eavestroughing on this building and the rain falling from the roof is wearing away the earth adjacent to the foundation. These are required, also a water tank installed in the basement to collect the water for the use of the school children in washing themselves, also in washing the school towelling, dishes, and scrubbing of the floors.

White labour will be required to install the eavestroughing and water tank as we have no Indians experienced in this work.

I recommend that the materials listed be granted and the work done.

Yours very truly,

S. H. SIMSON
INDIAN AGENT.

The Secretary,
Indian Affairs Branch,
Department of Mines and Resources,
Ottawa, Ontario.

Dear Sir:

Re: Estimates 1940-41.

I beg to enclose herewith form No. 37 in triplicate, listing material and labour required to dig a well for the Kinistino Day School and Teacher's Residence.

The old Department Farm well is practically dry and is not supplying sufficient water for requirements. The well cribbing is badly rotted in places. It is not wide enough to permit the placing of a new cribbing inside to allow the well to be deepened.

It is estimated that an adequate supply of water can be procured at a depth of between 45 and 50 feet.

The cost of the lumber listed is the price being charged by small sawing mills in the district adjacent to the reserve.

Dear Mr. Christianson:

Re: Page 8 b 1940-41 Estimates.

I am in receipt of a letter No. 109-6-5 dated March 28th, from Mr. Hoey, Superintendent of Welfare and Training advising that there is not sufficient funds in the appropriation for the fiscal year 1940-41 to provide for a new well for the Kinistino Day School and advises that I communicate direct with you regarding the matter.

The old Department well at the Kinistino Reserve from which the school has been procuring its supply of water is practically dry and is not producing nearly sufficient water for the requirements of the school, teacher's residence and Department livestock (namely 2 cows, 1 heifer, 2 bulls and 5 horses).

Duck Lake, Sask., November 1st, 1937

Sir,

I beg to report that while I was visiting the Kinistino Reserve on the 29th and 30th ultimo I noticed that a coal burning furnace had been shipped by the Winnipeg Paint and Glass Co., Winnipeg, to this Reserve to be installed in the new Indian Day School which is now under construction there.

This furnace is a straight coal burner, and the fire-box therein is so small that it would be impossible to heat the building by burning wood, which should be used for this purpose as there is at present an abundant supply of both dry and green wood on the Reserve. It could be supplied by the Indians at a cost of from $1.50 to $2.50 per cord, and would be a means of them receiving a revenue therefrom.

If this furnace is installed the Indians will be deprived of this revenue and the Department will be under considerable expense for many years by burning coal, as it will have to be hauled from 18 to 24 miles from the Railway to the Reserve, and would cost from $12 to $13.00 per ton delivered.

I was given to understand that the building would be ready for installation of the furnace by the 10th or 14th instant.

I would recommend that a wood-burning furnace with a fire-box large enough to take a four or five foot length of wood be shipped at once, and that the furnace now at the School be returned.

Your Obedient Servant,

S.H. Simpson,
Indian Agent.

Memorandum:

Dr. McGill

Re: New Day School, Kinistino Indian Reserve, Sask.

Final accounts have been received from Mr. G.H.L. Dempster in connection with the building of the above school showing that the total cost during the present fiscal year amounts to $4,961.00.

The amount provided in the Estimates for this project was $4,700.00 and the remaining $261.00 will be provided by a transfer from unexpended monies from Project No. 3.

The only work left uncompleted due to weather conditions is exterior paint work comprising staining the roof, painting the finishing coat on the outside of school building and two coat painting the privies. It is estimated that a sum of $50.00 will complete this work to and after March 31st next.

I would be glad if you could arrange to have this amount provided under the 1938-39 Estimates.

Director.

Duck Lake, Sask., February 21st, 1938

Dear Sir:

In reference to the third paragraph of Departmental letter No. 109-6-5, dated the 7th instant, pertaining to book-cases for the Kinistino Day School, I find that, upon enquiry there are no Indians on this Reserve who can build cupboards suitable for the purpose required. Mr. Gardner, the Teacher, also informs me that he has not had sufficient experience in carpentry work to undertake building a cupboard.

While at this School on the 17th and 18th instant, I found that the following items are required in addition to the above mentioned:

Kitchen cupboard for dishes, cooking utensils, etc.,
Wash-Stands (2)
Dining-room table,
Dining-room benches.

Plain lumber can be purchased and the work done at the School by a local carpenter much more cheaply than purchasing the articles ready-made.

As the cupboards will have to be built against the inside walls of the School it will be necessary that this work be done right at the School. Owing to the cost of travelling at this time of year I recommend that this work be left until the roads are passable next Spring.

Temporary arrangements for a dining-room table, benches and wash-stand are made and will suit the purpose for the time being.

Your Obedient Servant,

PUBLIC ARCHIVES ARCHIVES PUBLIQUES CANADA
Dear Sir:

I beg to attach requisitions for food supplies for the mid-day meal, Day Schools in the Duck Lake Agency.

I would point out that during the past school year the Department granted the sum of $50.00 each for these schools to be expended for the purpose just mentioned. At the end of the school term the Kinistino School, which was closed this Spring owing to an epidemic of flu, only used $31.00. The Fort a la Corne South School had an unexpended balance of $4.60. The other three schools used the amounts allotted to them.

I might also say that a close check is being kept on supplies provided for these meals, each school submitting a monthly report on the supplies received, used, and remaining on hand.

The supplies on these requisitions, with the exception of biscuits, have never been provided heretofore. They are to be used principally for the making of biscuits, bread and dumplings, with a view to trying to do away with the supplying of school biscuits.

With regard to the school biscuits supplied, I have discussed this matter with our teachers and agents. The general opinion seems to be that for the amount of money expended on biscuits, a more adequate meal could be supplied and a considerable saving effected. These schools are willing to try this out this season and I would recommend the request be allowed. I would also point out that it gives our teachers an opportunity to instruct the children in baking and cooking. It is, in my opinion, very important that these girls should be taught how to bake bread and that every effort should be used to get the Indians to abandon the making of bannock instead of raised bread, as not only is the raised bread preferable from the health point of view, but it would also greatly reduce the flour requirements.

Yours truly,

Thos. Robertson,
Inspector of Indian Agencies,
Saskatchewan.

The Secretary,
Indian Affairs Branch, Ottawa.

Ottawa,
August 8, 1939.

Dear Sir:

I am in receipt of your letter of the 29th ultimo with reference to the midday meal supplies at the day schools in the Duck Lake Agency.

I note that the requisitions which you forwarded requested supplies to be used in place of biscuits.

In this regard I may say that the biscuits have already been ordered and will reach the respective schools in the near future. Under these circumstances the items mentioned on the requisition forwarded with your letter of the 29th ultimo are not being ordered.

Mr. Phelan, Chief of the Training Division, will be returning East about August 24 and will stop off for a day in Regina in order to meet you and at that time you might discuss with him the whole question of midday meals at the schools in Saskatchewan.

Yours truly,

R. A. Hoey,
Supt. of Welfare & Training.

Dr. Thos. Robertson,
Inspector of Indian Agencies,
Regina, Sask.

- John Smith's Day School $50.00
- Fort a la Cerne Day School $45.00 North

Dear Sir:

Re: Estimates 1940-41.

I beg to enclose herewith Form #37 in triplicate listing materials required for the Kinistino Day School Building.

The basement of this school is used as a kitchen and dining room for the pupils of the school. The inside cement walls require finishing in order that they may be kept sanitary. Paint has been requisitioned for this purpose. It is considered that by using paint instead of Kalsomine it will permit keeping the walls clean by having them washed as they require it.

Screen windows were not provided when the school was constructed. Materials have been listed to make the screens required.

There is no eavestroughing on this building and the rain falling from the roof is wearing away the earth adjacent to the foundation. These are required, also a water tank installed in the basement to collect the water for the use of the school children in washing themselves, also in washing the school towels, dishes, and scrubbing of the floors.

White labour will be required to install the eavestroughing and water tank as we have no Indians experienced in this work.

I recommend that the materials listed be granted and the work done.

Yours very truly,

S. H. Simpson
Indian Agent.

The Secretary,
Indian Affairs Branch,
Department of Mines and Resources,
Ottawa, Ontario.

March 19, 1940.

Dear Sir:

Re: Estimates 1940-41.

I beg to enclose herewith form No. 37 in triplicate, listing material and labour required to dig a well for the Kinistino Day School and Teacher's residence.

The old Department Farm well is practically dry and is not supplying sufficient water for requirements. The well cribbing is badly rotted in places. It is not wide enough to permit the placing of a new cribbing inside to allow the well to be deepened.

It is estimated that an adequate supply of water can be procured at a depth of between 45 and 50 feet.

The cost of the lumber listed is the price being charged by small sawing mills in the district adjacent to the reserve.

I recommend that a new well be provided.

Yours very truly,

S. H. Simpson
Indian Agent.

Ottawa, Ontario.

Dear Mr. Christianson:

Re: Page 8 b. 1940-41 Estimates.

I am in receipt of a letter No. 109-6-5 dated March 28th, from Mr. Hoey, Superintendent of Welfare and Training advising that there is not sufficient funds in the appropriation for the fiscal year 1940-41 to provide for a new well for the Kinistino Day School and advises that I communicate direct with you regarding the matter.

The old Department well at the Kinistino Reserve from which the school has been procuring its supply of water is practically dry and is not producing nearly sufficient water for the requirements of the school, teacher's residence and Department livestock (namely 2 cows, 1 heifer, 2 bulls and 5 horses).

The cribbing in the well is badly rotted in places and is not wide enough to permit the placing of new cribbing therein and deepening the well.

It is estimated that an adequate supply of water can be procured at a depth of between 45 and 50 feet.

The cost of the lumber listed on the attached form No. 37 is recorded at the price being charged by small sawing mill outfits adjacent to the reserve.

It would be very much appreciated if you could grant this work being done from your appropriation.

Yours very truly,

S. H. Simpson
Indian Agent.

M. Christianson, Esq.,
Superintendent of Indian Agencies,
Indian Affairs Branch,
Department of Mines and Resources,
Ottawa, Ontario.

Memorandum: Mr. Roey.

In accordance with the suggestion contained in your letter to Mr. Simpson dated March 26th he has written to me regarding the digging of a new well at the Kinistino Reserve.

The estimated cost of the digging of a 45 foot well, including cribbing and installation of pump, is $110.80.

As the well would be used by the reserve as well as by the school I am of the opinion that the cost of same should be divided equally between your vote and Indian Agencies Vote. No funds have been specially provided for the purpose in the vote for Indian Agency purposes, but no doubt we can provide same by reducing some other item.

Kindly advise me whether you are able to provide 50% of the cost.

General Superintendent of Agencies.

M.W.

Dear Mr. Douglas:

This will acknowledge your letter of November 15 regarding the Kinistino Indian Reserve.

I shall deal with the various points raised in the order in which they appear in your letter.

You state that you are advised that the school is in a dilapidated condition and that no proper instruction is being received by the children. The records of the Department indicate that quite the contrary is the case, and that the Kinistino Indian day school is very far indeed from being neglected. As you are aware Indian schools in Saskatchewan are inspected by the Inspectors of the Province, and at this point I would like to mention that this arrangement works out admirably and is much appreciated. The last inspection of the Kinistino school reported was by Inspector L. Thorderson, and was made on July 25, 1946. The Inspector's general comment in his report is quoted as follows:

"The enrolment of 37 pupils seems to be quite good. The attendance during the winter months was very good. However, it has been very low during the month of June as most of the families are away from the reserve picking seneo roots. Four new desks have recently been received. More desks are needed to accommodate all the pupils. The library is being improved with suitable books. The school and equipment are in general quite satisfactory.

The pupils seem well nourished and well clothed.

Mr. Gardner is very interested in the welfare of the individual families on the reserve. Mrs. Gardner assists with work in connection with the health of the pupils and adults.

Commendable progress is being made."

The last previous inspection of the Kinistino school reported was by Inspector F.M. Glazier, and was made on October 27, 1944. The Inspector's general comment in his report is quoted as follows:

"An enrolment of 26 seems complete. The attendance has not..."
been good during the fall term owing to a number of families being off the reserve for harvesting.

The school continues to be the centre of the community. Pupils are taught cleanliness and nutrition. A hot cooked meal is served at noon. The school is equipped with cooking utensils, stove and wash basins.

Emphasis in the classroom is placed on writing and reading. Mrs. Gardner assists with the school lunch, sewing, knitting and spinning. Games are organized.

The children are well dressed and seem to be well nourished.

These reports speak for themselves and while both reports are favourable, it will be noted the latter shows a marked increase in enrolment.

Examples of recent expenditures by the Department on this school are as follows:

(a) On July 19, 1946, the following expenditures were authorized for repairs to this school.
   1. Repairing the school ............... $133.60
   2. Repairing teacher's residence ...... 79.18
   3. Cistern for teacher's residence ... 134.75

(b) On July 30, 1946, the six desks reported short by the Provincial Inspector were shipped.

(c) On August 29, 1946, the usual $50.00 for mid-day meal was authorized.

(d) On August 31, 1946, $27.50 was expended for veterinary services to the school cow.

(e) On October 23, 1946, $139.19 was paid for 600 lbs. special vitaminized biscuits supplied for school lunches.

(f) On August, 1946, usual stock of pencils, scribblers, texts, library books, and sporting supplies.

In the light of the foregoing, I believe you will agree that the information given you regarding this school was decidedly wide of the mark.

You state that as a result of a crop failure this year, the members of the Band are expected to suffer real privation.
On this question the Indian Agent reports that while the crops on the Kinistino Reserve did not suffer from lack of moisture, the yields were reduced due to the severe frosts experienced on July 24.

He also states that the Indians of the Agency generally are in receipt of a satisfactory income and there are very few cases of hardship or want.

You may rest assured, however, that the Department will take all the necessary measures to see that there is no avoidable hardship or privation on the Kinistino or any other Indian reserve.

There seems to be some misunderstanding on the part of your correspondents concerning the amount of the funds of the Kinistino Band, which were stated to you as some $20,000. As a matter of fact, the funds of this Band are at the present time $5,263.00 in capital funds. This Trust Fund was built up mainly from the interests of certain members of the Band in sales of reserve lands held in common by various groups of Indians many years ago. It has been conserved at approximately its present figure for some 30 years. Originally the amount was much smaller. Interest on the fund is allowed by the Government at the rate of 7% and it is administered and disbursed for the benefit of the Indians under the authority of the Indian Act for relief and other appropriate items such as fencing and repairs to farm machinery. It is at any time in order for the members of the Band to hold a meeting and make requests to the Department regarding expenditure of these funds through the office of the Indian Agent and such requests always receive sympathetic consideration subject, of course, to the Department's duty as trustee to see that the funds are spent wisely and according to law.

As to the question of Chief, there is no reason why the Indians should not hold a meeting to choose a Chief according to their Band custom. The more advanced election provisions of the Indian Act have not as yet been applied to this Band. These provisions are more suited to the requirements of Indian communities larger than the Kinistino Band, which according to the census taken in 1944, has a population of only 137. These election provisions moreover, have not been applied to any extent to Indians in Western Canada as yet, although they are in general use on the Eastern Reserves. It is the intention eventually to apply them generally. This objective, however, is being approached gradually because the election provisions when applied, supersede the original customs of the Bands and in some cases conflict to a certain extent with the establishment of Chiefs and Councillors enjoyed by the Indians under their
treaties. Until recently there has been little demand from the Indians themselves in the Western Provinces for the introduction of the new system and even yet it is by no means established that the majority wish to change.

The whole question, however, is one that will be reviewed thoroughly in connection with the activities of the Parliamentary investigation into Indian Affairs which began at the last Session and which, it is expected, will be continued at the next Session. In the meantime the wishes and opinions of the Indians in connection with this important problem are receiving most careful consideration.

In conclusion and in reference to all the points raised, may I suggest that it is at all times in order for any of the Indians who have complaints or grievances to submit them to the Department through their Indian Agents and Inspectors.

Copies of this exchange of correspondence are being forwarded to the Inspector of Indian Agencies in Saskatchewan, Mr. J.P.B. Ostrander, 414 Federal Building, Regina, for further inquiry locally, into the various subjects dealt with.

Yours sincerely,

Honourable T.C. Douglas,
Premier of Saskatchewan,
Regina, Saskatchewan.

Kinistino Reserve.

Entry of Daily Journal for month of August 1945

1. Daily Chores. At Reserve all day. Drove around & took at crops. Improving after the showers. Weather Bright & cool. Heavy showers & wind.

2. Daily Chores. Work from Dept. of Health. Dr. visited Reserve. Drove to Indian tents, inoculated vaccinated children, most of them for the 3rd time. Haying going on well at Spence Lake end of Reserve. H.S. loaded in three loads today for Capt. Stock. Jim Morrison has moved down to the Ranch for haying. Weather Bright & cool.

3. Daily Chores. Haying going on well. H.S. brought in 3 more loads of hay. Moved around sheep on Dell and grain farm. Weather Bright & fairly hot.

4. Daily Chores. Haying continuing at all points. Drove to Cat City for motor repair. Breaking for lumberjack. Haying land neglected by Jake Hippie. Weather Bright & warm.

5. Daily Chores. Breaking for Capt. on land & sparrow to enlarge the field overgrown yesterday. Haying going on satisfactorily. Land stacks put up at Spence Lake. Took a short tour of broken plough to Blacksmith at South Star. Truck filled with sand. Weather Cool. Wheel. Took to Cat City for new piping fitting. Weather Cloudy at times. Very long windy. Cool.

6. Daily Chores. Workday. Drove breaking a dummy fallow. Haying going on well at Spence Lake & Ranch. Stacking at Spence Lake. H.M. Ellwood left this morning for Rose Valley. Weather Cloudy threatening rain.

7. Daily Chores. Many men stopped haying.

Weather Exceptionally heavy rain last night. Water all over. Rainy most of day.

8. Daily Chores. At Reserve all day. Jim Morrison made arrangements with Mr. Hallett to help with haying at Spence Lake. Hallett to take care of the hay he himself will receive. To have one load per day when working with him. Weather Heavy rain last night. Showers today.

9. Daily Chores. Rain stopped all haying. Building a new fence in pasture East of school. Roads in very bad shape. Weather Heavy rain last night. Some rain this morning. Cloudy & cool later.

10. Daily Chores. Mr. Lorne went Reserve. He paid store bills, given on road work and left supplies for new employed. Still too wet for haying. Weather Cloudy threatening rain. Heavy rain last night.
Aug 11

1. Weather: Cloudy. I went to the Indian Hospital to get water for the furnace. Mr. Williams said he will come out on Tuesday to see what is needed.

2. Roads in bad shape except where gravelled. Weather Bright warm. Very heavy rain P.M. and evening.

3. Daily Chores: I've got to hang up. Taking out the pasture, putting in new fence and patching the other fences at the Indian Hospital. Weather: Hot and dry with heavy showers.

4. Daily Chores: That day. I've got to hang up the new fence. Also today I've got another fence to put up. Weather: Very heavy showers. Roads: Bad.

5. Daily Chores: Made a new fence around the pasture. Weather: Cloudy and cool. Cleaned up the yard.

6. Daily Chores: Visited the hospital and saw Mr. Gardner. I came back home to finish the fence. Weather: Bright warm.

7. Daily Chores: Worked on the fence. Weather: Bright warm.

25. Mr. Benson had his truck out in the morning, but there was no work. We took our time at 7:30 AM.

Weather: Cloudy at intervals, threatening rain, cool.

Daily chores: Stewart started harvesting corn stalks; plowing and tilling. No hay making until afternoon. Cutting and raking hay at Stone Lake. Agreed with Mr. MacMillan to help him with his hay making. He takes a share of the hay for his work. So far we have only fed our horses. We cut a lot of hay in the meadows at Stone Lake. They usually sell.

An emergency trip to the hospital with Mr. MacMillan's wife who gave birth to a daughter.

Weather: Partly cloudy, cool. Some of frost to night.

26. Daily chores: Mail day. Very strong wind blowing hay up. Worked on hay making operations at Stone Lake. Also packed a lot of hay together. Weather: Breezy with very high wind.

Weather: Bright and warm.

Weather: Bright and pleasant.

Weather: Hot and dry. Very high wind and electric storm in evening.

29. Daily chores: Mr. Brown driving breaking the fall crops. Weather: Bright and hot.

Lumberjack bought 1/2 last day for Dept. Stock.

8 Daily Chores School. Mr. Hanson took 5 Indians to Tisdale hospital. A blood transfusion was needed for Arthur Thomas. The doctor requested the attendance of three men. Weasel Nappi supplied the blood. This was the only blood suitable (group 3). Too damp for haying.

Weather: Cloudy AM. Bright PM.

9 Daily Chores School. Mr. Hanson took Jim Morrison to Tisdale Hospital. He has an infected foot from the injury inflicted on Aug 28th. E. Stewart painting outbuildings. Haying at Ranch. Some men out threshing.

Weather: Cloudy cool. Sharp frost last night.

10 Daily Chores School. Mail Day. Haying at Ranch. Oscar Hanson cut Macdonald's barley. Raked up grain feed on Norman Scott's land.

Weather: Cloudy with a few light showers.

14 Daily Chores School. Haying continuing. Men out threshing for S. Postnikoff. Weather: Bright & warm.

15 Daily Chores School. Haying. H. Phelan cutting oats for Weasel Nappi & Charlie Muskey. Wheat for Henry Scott.

Men stems out threshing. Men moving up from Ranch. Pitmen on binder broke. Got one in Star City. Blacksmith at South Star cut it to fit.

Weather: Bright cool.
16 Daily Chores & School. Emergency trip to Tisdale Hospital with Jean Nappi wife of Monroe Nappi. Called us up at 3 a.m. rushed her to hospital. Have been to a daughter soon after arrival.

Jim Mooreway came to the office at 9 a.m. His injured foot needed medical attention badly. Mr. Gardner took him to Tisdale hospital.

Lumberjack, Macdonald Bay, laying at Spence Lake. Norman Phelan cutting Henry Scott oats. Weather Bright & sunny.

17 Daily Chores & School. Norman Phelan finished cutting oats for Henry Scott. Started cutting for Norman Scott. Lumberjack Jim Mooreway laying at Spence Lake. But Nappi laying.

Drive to Nut Lake Reserve to see Mr. Stewart regarding hiring a man to run tractor over breaking and summerfallow. Weather Bright & cool.

18 Daily Chores & School. Norman Phelan cut oats on Dept seed grown farm. Cutting oats for Norman Scott. Henry Scott taking up & hauling in fresh feed.

Lumberjack & B. Nappi laying. Weather Bright & cool.

19 Daily Chores. Complaint brought in to Office that Old Muskeyo had been hurt last night by Maggie Nappi. Mr. Gardner & I went to investigate. Muskeyo's face was cut badly & his left arm injured. He says that Maggie Nappi came to his tent drunk, and when told to leave she struck him. Phoned RCMP Tisdale but could not contact them. Drive to Tisdale & saw Constable Anderson. The Police car was away but they will look into the matter tomorrow morning. Weather Bright & pleasant.

20 Daily Chores & School. RCMP visited Reserve Muskeyo laid a complaint against Maggie Nappi. Police talked her to the Office but she refused to plead. Case adjourned until Friday next at 1 p.m.

Haying & harvesting. Weather Bright & warm.
21 Daily Chores School. Haying shawesting. Mr. Hardman wrote to Mr. Keane to get roller for binder, to Star City to take Henry Scott to bring out tractor, in evening to South Star to get binder parts welded. Bought new school provisions. Weather Bright & warm.

22 Daily Chores School. Mr. Cowan came to Reserve. Mr. Hardman met him from the bus at Highway 35. Went to Post Office to Mr. Keane to arrange for delivery of grain. Weather Bright & pleasant.

23 Daily Chores School. Mr. Cowan fixed binder to. Food supplies at various stops on Reserve. Total 8 miles to Star City in evening for binder parts. Weather Bright & warm.

24 Daily Chores School. Mail Day. RCMP Mr. Marshall J.P. held trial of Maggie Hippie for assault on Muckey. Fine $50.00. Weather Bright & warm.

25 Daily Chores. Thrashed oats from Dept seed grain farm. Oscar Brown loaded grain into grainery. Hired Ben Hippie to help on long haul. Weather Bright & windy.

26 Daily Chores. S. Postnikoff loaded Henry Scott's oats + 7 acres of wheat. Thrashed Mac Smoky Bay's early. Weather Cloudy.

27 Daily Chores School. Mail Day. Rain last night stopped haying shawesting until afternoon. Mac Smoky Bay cutting oats. Fred Cow stocking oats. Tractor working on Dept. Building. Operator made heavy float this morning. Weather Cloudy. Rain last night.

28 Daily Chores School. Tractor on Dept. Building. Henry Scott cutting grain field. Mac Smoky Bay cutting oats. Haying at Jim Morroway's. S. Stewart painting school. Weather Bright & cool.

29 Daily Chores. School paint steps being painted so had to close school. Tractor working on Dept. building. Weather Bright & sunny. Field up 2 acres of hay. Henry Scott finished grain field. Drive to Regina with S. Postnikoff. Weather Bright with slight wind.

30 Daily Chores. Returned from Regina. P.M. Haying going on in Morroway's meadow. Henry Scott cutting oats. Tractor working on summer fallow. Weather Bright & pleasant.

Dear Sir,

With reference to the request for a Day School made by the Indians of Chitok Lake, N.W., of Wichekan Lake, SASK.; Archdeacon Paul visited this Reserve last week, and found sixty-one people on the Reserve, thirty-five of these being children, and seventeen of the children between the ages of six and fifteen. The Indians renewed their request for a school and promised that if a school were to be built they would send the children regularly, and would not take them away on hunting expeditions while the school was in session. Mr. Indian Agent Weir has visited this Reserve recently, and is in favour of a school being erected there. I am of the opinion that the best method of civilising these primitive Indians is to start a Day School among them, and I shall be glad to nominate a teacher if the Department is willing to inaugurate a school at this point. The Reserve consists of certain sections in Townships 54 and 55, Ranges 12 and 13 West of the third Meridian.

Hoping that the request of these Indians may receive a favourable reply from the Department,

Sir,

I have the honor to acknowledge receipt of your letter No. 107-7-1 dated November 18th, relative to a request received from the Anglican Church authorities for the establishment of a day school at Chitek Lake Reserve, to be conducted under their auspices.

This reserve is situated a considerable distance from Leask, only about thirty-five members receive annuity money the balance refusing to accept same. Their main livelihood is derived from hunting and trapping. In the past I have found it rather difficult to obtain much information from members of this Band though on my more recent visits they have appeared more friendly and inclined to discuss matters more freely with me. Under the present circumstances it is a difficult matter for me to say that if a day school was established it would prove a success. However, I would recommend that a school be established as we will not be able to make any progress until we commence educating Indians of this reserve.

This Band has received very little assistance from the Department in the past. If a school was established it would be necessary to erect a school, teacher's residence, stable and sink a well, the approximate cost would be $4500.00-$5000.00. The reserve is situated about 35-40 miles from a railway on the new Shellbrook-Turtleford branch of the Canadian National Railway. All lumber and material would have to be purchased at a considerable distance from the reserve which would entail considerable

Dear Sir:

In the year 1929 Anglican missionaries commenced visiting Chitek Lake Reserve and received some response from the Indians. In the time the Indians asked that a school be established on their reserve. Mr. John Weir, at that time Indian Agent, was anxious that a school be started there and asked the Church of England to cooperate. On Nov. 19, 1930, you wrote to Archdeacon Paul (No. 107-7-1) saying that you were not hopeful concerning the establishing of a school at Chitek the following year as funds for building were extremely limited. In Sept. 1931 Archdeacon Paul interviewed The Late Mr. Russell Ferrier and Mr. Williams at Ottawa concerning this project and they said that a school would be started when funds permitted. Since then owing to the depression the Department was still unable to carry on a school on that reserve but as the Indians were getting impatient and we had promised them to do our best to have a school established on the reserve, the Church of England having obtained authority from the Department, and through the interest of two Anglican individuals who made themselves responsible for the cost of the school, started a school in Jan. 1932.
The services of a white male teacher were secured, but since he and the Indians could not understand each other, the school was not a success to begin with. The following year a native teacher, Mr. F.J. Daniels who used to teach the Indian Department School on the Shoal Lake Reserve in the Pas Agency, was appointed instead of the previous teacher. As he could speak to the Indians in their own language they soon began to respond and to send their children to school, and the attendance has been slowly increasing since that time. The annual Holiday has usually been taken from the 3rd week in April until the end of June as the Indians were in the habit of going away for the muskrat season. For the months Sept. 1935 to March 1936 the attendance has been as follows:

| Month | Attendance |
|-------|------------|
| Sept. 1935 | 6.6        |
| Oct.    | 7.7        |
| Nov.    | 11.95      |
| Dec.    | 13.2       |
| Jan. 1936 | 12.5       |
| Feb.    | 7.5 (sickness and extreme cold) |
| Mar.    | 12.5       |

Average for seven months, 9.89.

The school has now started again for this academic year and I heard recently that the Indians had returned to the reserve and were sending their children to school. I feel that the time has now come when we may fairly apply to the Department to take over this school. There is a suitable log school house with a small addition used as a storeroom and a small teachersage. If the Department does not wish to take over the buildings we shall be very glad if it would provide the salary of the teacher and also biscuits, cocoa and etc., for the children's lunch.

Mr. Daniels is receiving a salary of $630.00 per annum which is the same as he received from the Department when at Shoal Lake. I feel that it should not be left to individuals to carry on this work which really belongs to the Indian Department and the church is unable to pay the salary of a teacher out of its Mission Funds. I hope that you will see your way clear to grant this request.

Dear Sir,

I have for acknowledgment your letter No. 107-7-1 of the 27th ultimo, relative to the question of the Department taking over the Day School on Chitek Lake Indian Reserve.

In my opinion I would not recommend that the Department take over the school for some time to come. It has been in operation for some years under the auspices of the Anglican Church, and I fail to see any real advancement in the pupils. Whilst the average attendance may appear to be good, I am inclined to think that the same children do not attend regularly, some are present on some days then they go off the parents and others take their place. These Indians are very backward and depend mainly upon hunting and trapping for a livelihood. I feel that the cost of operating this school would not justify the Department taking over for results to be obtained.

When the times does come for taking over this school I certainly would recommend that only white certificated teacher be employed. It has been my experience that when other than white are employed very little is accomplished.

Yours truly,

Indian Agent.
