Dear Sir:

Re Your Letter February 20th, File 303-11A.
Chitek Lake and Lac la Ronge Schools.

---

Chitek Lake School:

The school now operated on the Chitek Lake (Pelican Lake) Reserve is run by the Church of England, who receive a grant of assistance of $350.00 a year. They employ a half-breed as teacher, Mr. F.J. Daniels. It is not very satisfactory to have a half-breed teaching these Indians as his home conditions are very similar to the Indians. I believe that if a good teacher was employed, one who would take an interest in social service work, this Reserve would show a decided improvement.

If a school was built about 18' x 24', with a full size basement for vocational training, complete with a furnace, the cost would be about $1250.00. Most of this work could be done by the Indians by taking one of our good carpenter Indians from one of the other Reserves as foreman. Most of the lumber can be purchased in the vicinity of the Reserve from local saw mills at a very reasonable price. The walls of the school would be of log construction.

A small residence for the teacher would also needed to be built. It could be of log construction about 26' x 30'. This work could also be done by the Indians. I would estimate the cost to be about $1700.00. This cost includes a full size basement and furnace.

The Indians, with the exception of the foreman, could be paid in food supplies.

Lac La Ronge Schools, Sucker River:

This settlement at Sucker River, about 20 miles from Lac La Ronge, is one of the most progressive in the North. I would estimate that they would have about twenty children of school age. I expect to be going to Lac La Ronge shortly and could verify this estimate.

A log building.........
A log building 18' x 26' should be sufficient. It would be impossible to have a basement owing to the rock formation of the land. Another small building 12' x 15' could be erected for vocational training. These buildings would not need to be as well finished as an outside school to be satisfactory. It would be necessary to freight in the lumber for the floor, roof and shingles, windows and hardware. It would be impossible to freight these supplies into Lac La Ronge before next winter. The cost of the two buildings would be about $1,000.00. All the work would be done by the Indians who would receive rations. An outside foreman would not be needed as these Indians are fairly good carpenters.

It would also be necessary to build a log residence about 26' x 30'. This building would need a little better finishing than the school. The estimated cost would be about $1200.00 and built by the Indians in the same manner as the school.

Fisher River District at Lac La Ronge is another good settlement. I have not visited this point very often owing to the expense, and therefore I am not very familiar with the amount school children. However, I will investigate the matter thoroughly this summer when I am paying Treaty at Lac La Ronge. If this point is developed it would be necessary to duplicate the building proposed for Sucker River district, and build them in the same manner.

In the case of both Sucker River and Fisher River Indians, in the winter the parents go off into other districts to their trap lines and so it would be necessary to provide rations for the children attending the schools as is the case at Stanley.

The school which is now operating for ten months in the year at Stanley has proved to be a decided success. These children are getting a far better education to fit them for their future than they every would at any boarding school. On Saturdays and after school they do a little trapping, and also help fish for the school and seem more contented.

Pelican Narrows, while in Saskatchewan, comes under the Pas Agency and I am not familiar with this point. Before a school is started at this point it would be as well to investigate the matter and see that you would not be confronted with religious difficulties.

Yours truly,

(Signed) R. S. Davis, Indian Agent.

Dr. T. Robertson,
Regina, Sask.

I have for answer your letter of May 23, and I am pleased to know that Mr. Umpherville will be on his way north by now. I was very sorry to hear about Mr. Heathcote but note that he will be able to take over the school in 1950.

I also have Mr. Cuthand's application for the school at Chitek. We have checked over the previous inspector's reports, and I do think he should be a very satisfactory teacher at this new school. With his background of teaching experience and army experience, he should be able to do a great deal with the Indians at Chitek.

I note that you are still endeavouring to secure a teacher for Pelican Narrows.

Sincerely yours,

Bernard F. Neary,
Superintendent of Education.

On a recent requisition from the teacher of the Chitek Lake School there was the following request:

Repairs to Buildings:

The school on the Chitek Lake Reserve is owned by the Anglican Church also the teacher's residence. The school is a log construction 20'x28' both the building and contents should definitely be replaced immediately funds are available. The teachers residence in nothing more than a shack and should be replaced also. The school at Stanley is operated for four months of the year, and the building is the property of the Department. This school 28'x34' is of log construction and is beyond all doubt a disgrace to our Department, likewise the teachers residence which is also of log construction.

The other seven day schools in this Agency all need a certain amount of repairs and redecorating, particularly the Mistawasis Day School. The teachers homes are in various stages of deterioration.

Ottawa, August 6th, 1947.

Mr. J.F.B. Ostrander, Inspector of Indian Agencies, Regina, Sask.

We have your letter of the 29th ultimo with reference to the proposed new school at Chitek Lake.

The Department desires this school to be as centrally located as possible and consequently we have no objection to it being erected on a new site. Are the Indians willing to donate a site for this school?

The plan which we sent to you was for a one room school with teachers living quarters included. Consequently, if this building were erected there is no necessity for applying to the church authorities for the residence formerly used by the teacher.

It is noted from Mr. Jones' letter that Mr. Axel Olsen of Waskeanu has expressed a desire to erect this building. Please obtain a quotation from him and forward it for our consideration as soon as possible.

As you know, we have to obtain an Order in Council before proceeding with the work and in order to prepare this document we require a tender from the builder.

I am in receipt of Department letter of the 26th instant, File No. 1-1-5 (W T), in connection with proposed prefabricated one-room Indian day school combined with teacherage, and the remarks therein have been noted. There are two matters in connection with the possibility of the erection of the prefabricated building at the Chitek Lake Reserve which must be considered. First, that we ordered a prefabricated house for the Farming Instructor at the Aesasekouche Reserve, or the Pelly Agency, on a good road, and quite convenient to Winnipeg by road, some time ago, and the company have been stalling us for over a month in the completion of this building after the basement was completed. They have still not started work on it and are now giving as a reason the fact that there is 13 miles of dirt road over which to haul material but Mr. Bryant informs me this is not correct and that it is all gravel road. I am inclined to believe that this company are taking on more work than they can promptly handle and we are probably going to find that if we order one of these buildings from them now it will be done some time next year. The other factor which should be considered is that if the order is placed with this company the basement and foundation should be completed at once before cold weather sets in, otherwise it cannot be done until probably next May.

I would be interested to know how the completed price of the prefabricated building will compare with the quotation of about $15,000.00 received from Axel Olson and submitted to the Department. The building should be fully insulated with a full basement, and supplied with a hot air furnace of suitable capacity. It should be remembered also that Mr. Olson's quotation included two outside toilets. These are fairly substantial buildings and add considerably to the cost. The point which I wish to make in this connection is that if the classroom and teacherage and the two outside toilets had been ordered from Mr. Axel Olson...
ordered from Mr. Axel Olson at the time that the tender was submitted they would have been completed this year and I am very doubtful that they will be completed this year by dealing with the North American Buildings Limited.

Colonel Heary:

Proposed school at Chitik Lake, Sask.

The delaying action regarding this school is justifiable on the following grounds:

1. Enrollment (1946) is mostly Anglican probably.
2. Child population 25, of these, a few are Catholic and most are non-Christian.
   Parents adverse to treaty and family allowances.
3. The contract price is very high, amounting to $1,000 per pupil likely to be enrolled.
4. Any contractor or crew we can pick up would be better employed on a more useful project.
5. Prince Albert is only 106 miles by rail. It is the Anglicans for whom facilities are needed.
   Delmas or Onion Lake would take the Catholics as Meadow Lake will lighten the load of the last two.
6. This land needs a haven of improved persons to offset the primitives. So far the day school's efforts have accomplished little. The impact of the people has pulled down the school and the former teacher to a low level. When a road goes through that area and civilization makes some headway we might induce a worthwhile teacher to go in. Only the Church can guarantee a competent missionary-teacher, some new cheaper installation might be a fair use of public money.

Mr. Ostrander heard me to this effect at Prince Albert on 18 June and seemed to agree.

Memorandum:

DEPUTY MINISTER

I am in receipt of Mr. Jackson's memorandum enclosing the attached correspondence in connection with the school question on the Big River Indian Reserve.

For several years a day school has been conducted on the Big River Reserve under the auspices of the Church of England. This building is very old and for some time past the Inspector of Indian Agencies and the Indian Agent have been urging the Department to replace it by a new building.

During the past year representations have been made for the establishment of a day school on this Reserve under Roman Catholic auspices and it has been pointed out to us that the Catholic children are sufficiently numerous to justify the establishment of a school.

Reports were obtained from the Inspector of Indian Agencies for the Province of Saskatchewan and after giving these very careful consideration it was decided to erect one Indian day school on the Big River Reserve to be conducted under the auspices of the Church of England and another Indian day school on the same Reserve to be conducted under Roman Catholic auspices.

On July 19 a requisition was forwarded to the Purchasing Agent, Mr. Bailey, for the material required for both schools.

Elle doit être remise au ministère, qui en garde un exemplaire et envoie les deux autres au délégué en chef du Trésor.

"Chef de famille" signifie une personne mariée, homme ou femme, une personne (homme ou femme) célibataire ou divorcée, ou une personne vivant dans un établissement domestique d’un seul tenant, et qui y fait vivre réellement une personne entièrement à sa charge, lui étant une ou les liens du sang, du mariage ou de l’adoption.

(i) "Établissement domestique d’un seul tenant" signifie un logis, un appartement ou autre semblable lieu de résidence contenant au moins une chambre à coucher, et dans lequel, en règle générale, l’employé couche et où ses repas sont généralement pris.

(ii) Une personne unie à l’employé par les liens du mariage signifie son époux ou épouse, les père, mère, oncles, tantes neveux, nièces, grands-parents et arrière-grands-parents du conjoint de l’employé, les beaux-frères, belles-sœurs, beaux-frères et belles-sœurs de l’employé.

(iv) L’expression "unie à l’employé par les liens de l’adoption" comprend l’adoption de fait aussi bien que l’adoption légale.

Dear Father Plourde:

Sister Cecilia de Jesus, the new teacher at the Big River R.C. School, has forwarded to the office the forms which I sent you with my letter of July 8. The forms are completed in French and there is also an accompanying letter written in French. It is unnecessary for me to state that I have no objection to the French language, nor have I any objection to receiving letters in French. However, there is another principle involved. Last fall Inspector Coleman visited some of the northern agencies in British Columbia and he reported that many of the missionary teachers in that section were unable to give instruction in English, although they were located on reserves where the Indians had not spoken French. This situation came to the attention of the Minister's office and it was intimated at that time that any teacher that we appointed should have a good knowledge of the English language when they are teaching among Indians who do not speak French. I feel that a similar situation will arise in the Carlton Agency if the new teacher is unable to give adequate instruction in English. I think you will agree with me in this particular matter and would appreciate your ascertaining if the new teacher is totally bilingual.

I am leaving for my holidays on the 13th or 14th and, if at all possible, would appreciate receiving your reply before that time.

Yours truly,
